The game itself I can recommend. It's insanely addictive, fun, has a great lore, and the amount of liberty you have to develop your colony offers you great narratives. The events also keep you tense to the point you start to prepare your colony and make plans for any situation, even though most of the time they can be unexpected.

The modding community also keeps the game alive and beating, while in other modding scenes a mod author just refuses to let someone else to update it, effectively killing it forever (I see you, ETS2/ATS community), in RimWorld's case it seems like common sense to keep them going strong, with the author who's no longer willing to keep a mod up to date often granting the chance of another group to fork it to a new version as long as given credit, saving player's saves from incompatibilities.

I've had plenty of good times with this game and for this reason I was happy to support it, and for that the staff and the modding community have my thanks.

Everything has a negative side, however, which is the constant "cult" status towards the developer. Every decision and every word from the dev is righteous, and must be defended at all costs. It's pretty embarrassing to watch, specially in subreddits. 

The pricing is also scandalous, with the complete aversion to sales hurting any interested players not living a cushy life in North America or Europe. God forbid someone from Latin America complain about dropping half their monthly salary into a game that will never see any sales other than an extremely rare 10% discount, specially when said game raised all its prices for the miserable parts of the planet during a global recession, with the DLCs being almost the same price as the base game. Easy to talk shit about "beggars" when you earn more in a day than most do in a month. Ironically, even though I threw a shade on the modding community for SCS Software, the devs themselves seem more considerate towards their fanbase than Ludeon Studios have ever seemed to be, which paid them off on the long run.

So, if you have the means, buy the game and its DLCs (who knows how many there will be, right? Sure hope there won't be some Paradox Interactive practices going forward). They are worth your time, and you'll likely be glad. If you're waiting for a sale for this, however, just do yourself a favor and keep it out of your wishlist: it won't happen and even if it does, it will be such a pathetic discount you might as well be paying full price already. Games are expensive, but there's a reason why RimWorld seems to have more pricing complaints than other titles.

Edit: Ironically, as of February 18, 2023, a further price drop is announced... But only for developed countries and still no word about sales. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
126016900.developer_response:
Hey there, thanks for the review.

I thought it was worth a comment regarding pricing. We use regional pricing to try to make the game available to everyone worldwide.

We have not followed Steam's official recommended regional pricing practices - we have set the price lower than Steam's recommendations in nearly every case.

You can see the list of prices at this page below on SteamDB. Lookin the rightmost column to see the discount we've given compared to Valve's recommended price:

 https://steamdb.info/sub/41602/

You mentioned Latin America. As you can see, all Latin American countries get discounts (up to 65%) from the base price. And all of those discounts except Costa Rica are deeper than what Steam recommends. For example, the Argentinian price is 65% lower than USD, and 13% lower than Steam's recommendations. The Colombian price is 62% lower than USD, and 20% lower than Steam's recommendations.

I'm hoping you and anyone reading will consider these facts in deciding whether we're doing wrong on pricing. Being cheaper than Steam's recommendations in almost every case doesn't seem to me like something that is "scandalous".

In any case, I'm glad you've loved the game so much.

Cheers.

128880185.review:
Reader beware, I ramble and I don't edit. The TLDR is I have some complaints but even on days the game hates me, I stick around for the excellent modding community. The DLC is good enough I caved and got it even though I'm usually frugal. There are war crimes here; rimworlds do not have a geneva to host conventions in I guess.


While I have some complaints, at 1600 hours in I can safely call this game compelling. Rimworld poses itself as a story generator moreso than a game, and by and large this works. Losing one of your colonists (or 'pawns') hurts in a mechanical and sometimes emotional capacity. The variable difficulty works well, especially with custom settings. Quests let you ratchet up the difficulty more, if you want.

THE GOOD:
-extremely customizable colonists. they have innate qualities and things they like to do, but these are strong suggestions moreso than hard limits. 
-immense capacity for depth. in vanilla alone, you can make cyborg super-soldiers with high-power combat stimulants. with DLC, that soldier can be a vampire catgirl cultist with royal titles. either way, that colonist can have enemies and lovers and distant relations. 
-variability in playstyles. single colonist runs are viable, increasingly more so with the DLCs. clone-spawned army? cybernetics cult? tree-worshipping nudist mages? all possible, easily, if you grab the addons.
-the modding community is stellar. Especially the few mod maintainers running around. Sincere kudos to you all.
-colonists *can* be ressurrected, but chances are rare and their body has to be preserved at cryogenic temperatures. that means protecting both a tomb and its refrigeration unit during enemy waves, if you want them back. Adds a lot of tension to some fights.

THE CONS
-so much cool stuff is DLC. I don't begrudge the devs that but if you're on a budget, definitely be aware.
-The War Crimes Thing (see below)
-performance gets worse as the game goes on. I have a suite of mods to remedy this. Some of it is my fault, I also have a suite of mods to use up as much performance as I gain back from the first batch.
-there is (or at least used to be?) some reductive and unnessesary things in the backend, particularly in how pawns form relationships and stuff like that. things like men primarily flirting with women instead of a roughly even distribution. As with most things, there's a mod for that.
-the mildest personal gripe: in the colonist name RNG table there's someone named 'poopy' and i devmode smite them every time they spawn. I'm sure theres a way to change the names list but i always forget to look. (this and bugtesting/bugfixing are the only reasons i leave dev mode accessible).
-some events are annoying and, in my opinion, don't add as much as they remove. both the [ZZZT] and [Solar Flare] events mess with the player's power grid, and the latter stops any electrical devices from working at all. End result, a colonist you were preserving for later revival can decay too far and fully die before you even have a chance at an item to revive them. This adds frustration instead of tension, imo. Mild complaint though, since events can be disabled individually on world generation.

THE WAR CRIMES THING
 This game lets you do a lot of unethical shit. None of it is required, most of it is entirely avoidable. However, the mechanical rewards for being ethical are minimal and the punishments vary. However, giving your colonists cocaine to counteract the mood debuff of organ harvesting is a valid strategy and that bears mentioning. From a purely mechanical standpoint, there are a lot of benefits to being a terrible person to these digital beings.

Benefits that I personally avoid reaping. For the most part. I admit, dog-murderers have been sent home from my colonies with peg legs and one lung shorter of breath.

And that's the good and the bad of this game in a nutshell. It's compelling. It makes you care. And, with so many options available to ruin fictional lives, it's easy to be tempted. Much like being a full author, I'm told. So, I suppose rimworld is a success then. A compelling machine that generates stories.

124047616.review:
When I first heard of Rimworld, I loved the premise. As a colony sim junkie and massive fan of video games that give me the opportunity to be creative and larp, it sounded perfect for me. Based on the description and the reviews-- especially the average number of hours players had-- it seemed like it delivered on its promises to be a highly varied, fresh, creative, and randomized experience every time.

My first 50 hours were great. I was totally captivated by my first game once I got a hang of the mechanics. I liked it so much, in fact, that I literally bought a second copy the same week. I got bored of my first colony, felt like I could do something better on a Randy Random, commitment mode, higher difficulty world, so I tried it. Worked out great, so I then made a third colony with the naked brutality start.

What I started to realize at this point was that as much as the game likes to pretend to be highly variable, fresh, fun, and random; characters constantly at the mercy of the storytelling AI as well as their own humanity, disasters, peculiar events-- basically, all those promises were pretty superficial. Every time I made a colony, I felt like it was the same story all over again.

Rimworld claims to be a story generator, but it really only generates the same story over and over. After three colonies, there's no more fun to be had with vanilla Rimworld without expansions. Though the characters have their silly little traits and partake in their own quirky behaviors, and maybe I'll be attacked by something that the RNG makes a little funny by complete chance, it's just so superficial and repetitive. No matter how many variables I try to play with in the settings, or whatever start I go with, whatever map I go with, I always end up with the same story revolving around even more lackluster and disappointing tower defense.

Many of you might not relate to what I've said at all, and I bet that's because the vast majority of RimWorld players use mods. Sure, if the content gets stale, I should just mod, right?

Here's where I have my major issue with Rimworld: it's a fucking $34.99 story generator that runs out of ideas after three playthroughs and from then on relies on mods to have any replayable value. I have absolutely no issue with small studios and independent game developers earning their fair share for their hard work-- on the contrary, this is actually super important to me. But I start to have a bit of a problem with this when the team behind Rimworld doesn't deliver.

The game has some issues that people have been complaining about for a while now: the wealth system being irritatingly illogical, certain quality of life features being completely nonexistent, colonist priorities being misevaluated, a lack of content diversity, etc. Have any of these been fixed on vanilla Rimworld? I don't think so, but feel free to correct me if I'm wrong. "There are mods to fix that"-- Yeah, I'm fully aware, but people are paying Ludeon $34.99 for Rimworld and receiving absolutely no updates to the base game, not even quality of life fixes that are so represented in the most downloaded mods. No, instead, we get offered DLC that costs half the price of the entire game.

Again, I respect artists and game developers-- but charging literally half the price of an already pricey base game (that never goes on sale) for content that makes the base game more likely to fulfill the promise it made players isn't cool. Honestly, Biotech was my breaking point. Babies have absolutely fucking nothing to do with anything in the rest of the DLC, but instead of adding them as an update to the base game, they were still lumped into the paid package because Ludeon is so opposed to improving and updating the base game without being paid.

Take a look at Terraria, for instance: it's a third of the price of Rimworld and the developers not only continuously make minor improvements to the game, but in the past two or three years have released not one, but two HUGE updates that were literally game changing and added so much extra content to the game. Not only this, but these updates were done with the community in mind, with the developers reaching out to players to ask them what they wanted to see in the game.

Concerned Ape, the guy who made Stardew Valley, released a huge, completely free update with long-time players in mind all while he was working on his newer game. He could've easily charged for this content as DLC, and that would've been totally fine, but it was added as an update with older players in mind in order to reward them for playing the game so long and give them a chance to achieve perfection.

I'm not saying that all small developers need to add huge updates for free, but what I'm trying to point out is the difference between these developers and Ludeon, which follows a model similar to Paradox: have a boring base game and charge for DLC to make it a little less boring. With Ludeon's business model, it's against their interest to add to the base game, as that takes away from paid content they could add as DLC. I don't feel like I can continue to support a studio that operates on this model.

I feel so out of place seeing everyone's reactions to the new DLC. I'm sure many people find it completely acceptable to charge this much for DLC, and to even charge $35 for the base game despite the fact that it never gets updated and has many flaws that could easily be fixed, but I don't find it acceptable anymore. And I don't find it acceptable to charge so much for a game that needs so many mods to be interesting after a certain point. I feel as though this will only get worse as time goes on, and that it isn't a productive strategy for Ludeon in the long run (unless you fucking troglodytes keep buying $25 DLC).

134675766.review:
I would summarize Rimworld as somewhat of a flawed gem with a longevity that depends on your ability to maintain suspension of disbelief. 

The premise is quite appealing, at least to me, as is the early gameplay. Frantically deal with the elements, setting up an early camp, dealing with an opportunistic early raid by 3-4 bandits... That part is quite immersive. As is planning out a more extensive base, setting up schedules for your colonists, adding defenses, etc. Having to deal with the pawn psychology is an interesting concept and it does make for some interesting stories, so it's not hard to see why the game is considered a story generator. It does start to get silly when a colonist snaps and wants to hide from the world in her room... but only after first getting her favourite snack of insect jelly, which right at that moment only exist in a room with an active infestation of megaspiders the rest of the colony is dealing with by torching it. Never mind there's two lines of heavily armed soldiers preventing murder bugs on fire from trying to escape the inferno, Cella wants her jelly and pushes her way past them, munches some jelly, then runs around on fire before expiring.

Stories like the above will abound, but for me they quickly turn into a story of bad AI and entirely unrealistic behaviour.

Unfortunately, once the latter part of the game comes around the stories start becoming borderline insane and not at all endearing. While I can understand the AI of the enemies trying to storm the base is not the best, the way the game is set up to try and provide a challenge is by essentially throwing more mobs at you and all reason out the window. As a specific example, in my last game my mountain base with a roughly 10 m thick wall of bedrock at the thinnest point gets attacked by Neanderthals wielding clubs, knives and spears (literally). The game warns me they'll try to circumvent my defenses. Which these Neanderthals are apparently able to do. Not only do they magically know where this thinnest spot is, they wait around while a single member in their gang spends an in-game hour (a relatively short amount of time, less than a minute) to stab his way through 10 m of bedrock using his spear. Which magically doesn't break.

Do not expect basic understanding of physics to be applicable in this game. There are other enemies that can melt their way through bedrock, such as mechanoid thermites (think burrowing robots with cannons); while fantastical I can understand them being a threat, and it's sci-fi so suspension of disbelief is preserved, but Neanderthals with spears ...?

On the plus side, there is a very active modding community so you'll be able to adjust the game to match the way you wish to play. And you can adjust your scenario by quite a bit, so your experience on the Rimworlds may be very different from mine.

129615350.review:
RimWorld is a game I wanted to love, but it just isn't fun. 

You are not leading a group of rag-tag survivors through brutal winters, existential threats, or interpersonal drama; instead you are there to troubleshoot the terrible AI and micromanage every action. 

The game has been built over a long period of time and you can tell. Systems are tacked on to one another, menu options are scattered nonsensically through the games 12 important menus (excluding the many expansion menus that were added). The game has a ton of complexity creep and almost no quality of life updates. The expansions do nothing to address these core faults. 

Troubleshoot, micromanage, defend from disaster, die. It's a tedious system to manage overall. Most of these problems can be fixed with mods, but the developer is over-reliant on mods to make the game playable. 

After 342 hours of learning the ins-and-outs, it's time to put it down for good. Maybe Rimworld II will fix all the annoyingly frustrating parts of the game, but this version of Rimworld is only for those hardcore min/maxers or creative players who turn off/down all of the threats.

129638584.review:
Given how much I like it, I can't not recommend this game. (Btw, don't look at my playtime here, I played this game a fair bit on someone else's account before I got it on mine).

However, unpopular opinion warning & criticizm ahead:
In my opinion, the pricing is straight outrageous. I wouldn't recommend this game at all if not wide variety of really awesome mods that add a whole lot of content as well as offer plenty of simple, not game-breaking, quality of life tweaks, as well as performance boosters.

The base game (without mods) is like paying for game's demo, with very little to actually do. Maybe call my imagination limited, but to me there's just not enough here to justify 30+ USD pricetag, (~150 of my currency, which is more than 10% minimal wage).
Without the DLCs (at least Ideology and Biotech) mods are an absolute must, at least to me, and by putting pricetag this high it feels like creator is literally asking you to pay this much for game's engine + mod access.

I feel like 30$/150 would be reasonable for current "base game" +Ideology +Biotech, maybe 35-40$, while it's actually [b] twice [/b] that price, a price of a triple A tittle (which year or two post release tend to get a massive discounts, like 50%. Often 60-75% off after 3 years+). Here? Discounts are practically nonexistant, at least in my country. The highest discount I saw in 4 years period was 10%. Only this Christmas, for the first time I believe, there was 20%, and it was for "base game only". which actually had its base price increased over time.

Call me stingy with my money, but to me as well to at least 4 other people I know, share the same exact opinion. I'm not the first one who sees this price as way too high. Not to mention I saw plenty posts online where many people say that they see it as very, very expensive.

PS: And to those that say "It's worth the money", "It's not a problem", tell me, did you bought it, or did your parents did? Because if it's the second, you can't say it's not expensive if its not you who paid for it, and If the first, how much are your earnings? I can guarantee, just because it may not a problem for [b]you[/b] specifically or someone in your family, that doesn't change the fact that many, many other people around the world have worse financial situation. And yes, it doesn't mean that every product should be "made affordable for them", but a single game, game that doesn't have a whole lot in terms of graphics or music, and wasn't made by some famous mark, shouldn't cost them a sizable chunk of their monthly income to play it.

Oh also, do you use mods, or is "100% vanilla" perfectly fine to you? Because if you use any mods, that means you aren't quite happy with the product, you would like more out of what it is, and that "something more" isn't - or at least shouldn't - be a part of the price. Just sayin.

Hate me if you like, I stand by my opinion.

141855298.review:
RimWorld is an amazing game that combines the elements of Strategy, Simulation and Storytelling to create an immersive and addictive experience. Set in a sci-fi world, the game challenges you to command a group of stranded survivors on a distant planet and build a thriving colony while overcoming numerous obstacles along the way.

One of the most impressive aspects of RimWorld is its dynamic and complex AI-driven storytelling. Each colonist has a unique personality with traits, abilities, and backstories that shape their behavior and interactions with others. This makes for a compelling and often unpredictable narrative that unfolds as you play. The game beautifully interweaves the events, crises, and stories of the individual characters to make you feel emotionally connected to the colonists and connected to their survival.

The game mechanics of RimWorld are deep and diverse. You must manage resources, construct buildings, grow crops, research technologies, and defend your colony against various threats such as hostile wildlife, bandits, and even raiders. The level of control and customization is excellent, allowing you to customize your experience through mod support and a wide range of game settings.

The game`s visuals may appear simplistic at first glance, but they effectively convey the atmosphere and convey the game's underlying depth. The pixel art style adds charm and allows smooth performance even on less powerful systems. The sound design and music complement the gameplay beautifully, increasing the immersion and enhancing the overall enjoyment.

RimWorld offers incredible depth and replayability, but can be very difficult for beginners. For those unfamiliar with similar simulation and strategy titles, the learning curve is steep and the game's complexity can be overwhelming. Additionally, some players may find the micro-management required to maintain a successful colony tedious or frustrating, especially in times of emergency or crisis. Overall, RimWorld is a masterpiece game that combines strategy, simulation, and storytelling into a truly unique experience. A dynamic AI-driven narrative, deep game mechanics, and endless possibilities make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Despite a difficult learning curve and occasional micromanagement frustration, RimWorld rewards your patience with countless hours of engaging and addictive gameplay. 

Buy it.

125663233.review:
One of the best games I have ever played. The replayability is amazing, the difficulty can be tweaked with ease, the modding community is vast and extremely welcoming and of course the game itself is so versatile that you can do anything you put your mind to.

Want to found a colony of cannibals that uses their victims skin for furniture and clothing, you got it. 
Want to make a vibrant sprawling city without risk of being attacked, sure.
Want to try and survive naked in the harsh wilderness and tame a family of bears for company, of course!

With the scenario editor and DLC's you can make pretty much any scenario or weird and wacky adventure you can think of, and if there are any shortfalls in the base game that you wish was a feature (magic, lightsabers, space battles and exploration) you can bet there is a mod to help you out.

I have had this game for a looooong time, and played it long before it was on steam. It is one of the few games I never uninstall, and even if I take a break for a month or so, I always come crawling back. If you can afford it, I highly recommend getting it.

lots of amusing stories from this game but they do blur together after a few hundred hours. of recent note for me were my non-combatant violence-incapable pig surgeon pig woman overdosing on mega cocaine combat enhancer during one of the endgame raids and dying immediately, and a colonist needing to be frantically micromanaged to put her baby into the shuttle that takes you off the planet and ends the game because she couldn't stop vomiting from food poisoning and dropping her baby on the ground. the cute little touches are really a big deal to me, genuinely heartwarming and funny: babies giggling and crying, the little RNG status reports when a child has a growth milestone that read like they're written *by* a child ("little Beaver learned a lot about medicine by watching people get sick and die; he wants to save the world and enjoys gossiping about animals"), the fact that the artwork your pawns make portrays actual events from your colony's history, stragglers seeing your lantern festival from far away and coming to visit and bring you a christmas tree.

i came for the city builder space shit, but stayed for the demented social sim.

Pro tips: 
There are a lot of ways for fire to ruin your life. Don't stick with using Wooden walls and floors for too long or you will regret it 100% of the time.

You can avoid nuking your base with the Zzzt event by dividing one big collection of batteries into multiple, smaller power stations Try not to have a lot of batteries per station, because the electrical explosion + fire event is based on how much power you've got stored.

Building a 5x5 bedroom gives you enough space for a double bed, an end table, a dresser, the smallest table and chair, a light source and the low tech wood cooler whose name I forget. All the amenities plus the bonus "It's roomy in here" mood will remove all bedroom related grievances you'll deal with.

124373361.review:
The only thing that stopped me from playing Rimworld in the beginning were the graphics. To be frank, it's not a pretty game. Since then, I've learned that often times a game without the prettiest face can be one of the best in the industry.

Rimworld is a colony/sim management game, and what it has in spades is a fantastic community of mod builders. Mods are the reason why I can go back to some games even after tens of years, and people like Oskar Potocki and co. help keep this sort of game alive. Not only alive, but thriving. Look at the reviews, don't look at me, that Overwhelming Positive status is all you need to know.

If you want a game that will give you the breathing room to do other things on the side, like listen to podcasts or watch movies, then pick up Rimworld. But, believe me, you are going to want to do something else while playing it, otherwise it'll more then eat up time, it'll devour it whole.

132417518.review:
I love sandbox like games and good stories. When I read "driven by an intelligent AI storyteller", got a recommendation from an acquaintance and saw so many positive reviews I had to try it. I thought the price is a bit steep but if it can deliver what it promises it's totally worth it. So I got the game and played several hours thinking "This is a nice base builder but I wonder when I get to experience story...". I really tried to get into the game and continued playing. After a while it started to get quite frustrating to continue. I don't see it delivering what it promises. It gets very repetitive with a lot of micromanagement and no story.

I now have over 40h of playtime and my 3rd colony. All quests I've seen are either "attack this base", "rescue someone from bad guys", "deliver x amount of y" or something inbetween. All the story generator seems to do is randomly select attacks, quests and things happening to colonists from a limited pool of scenarios. They have no influence on future events and nothing changes. Unless a colonist dies it also doesn't affect gameplay much.

I have to say that I thoroughly love this game. Not just because of the game play, which I absolutely enjoy, but because the devs had enough foresight to not only make an amazing game, but to include and encourage mods.

Do you like strategy/building/upgrading/total imagination with birds eye view games, while totally deciding if you want world peace or create a massive army to take over the entire world? This may be for you.

Farming? Check. Crafting? Check. Base defense? Check. Exploring? Check. Raising animals for possible consumption? Check. Leveling your pawns? Check. Raiding neighboring towns/villages/bandits? Check. Cannibalism? Check. I could go on.

The ability to adjust the game to your playstyle is absolutely second to none. In my 35+ years of gaming, this Rimworld adjustment of difficulty is legit. And I mean truly adjust. Not that bland garbage where everything but absolute max difficulty is about the same. Where max difficulty is lazy coding, like certain FPS games when you shoot one bot, every other bot within 1 KM finds you and turns you into Swiss cheese.

The vanilla game is downright awesome. Amazing even. You want a relaxing paced game? You got it. You want it to be more challenging? Boom, settings. You want to play a game that stresses you out, thus having nightmares because you thought you were tough enough to defy the devs when they can play god and absolutely wreck everything you built and dared to dream about? Here you go. They tried to warn you.

Did they release new updates that break all your mods? No big deal. Go to the game’s properties and then betas and roll that Bisquick back. They allow you to roll back the version to allow you to enjoy the mods from a previous iteration!!!!! If that isn't love for the players, I don’t know what is! And honestly, I want to know what love is. I want you to show me. (lyrics) 

The devs totally did. And I truly appreciate it. Thank you!

140002220.review:
Was skeptical at first, due to it's visual simplicity and unappealing UI. Didn't touch it for several years. Couldn't even imagine how much life, beauty and depth is hidden underneath it's simplistic looks. When I finally decided to give it a try and forced myself to spend at least 7-10 hours learning the basics, I was sucked in almost immediately. It's not just an extremely entertaining, intricate and deep colony management game. It is a simulation of life, characters, appearances, relationships, drama, health, war, friendships, climate, weather, flora, fauna and so on (Ideology and Biotech deliver even more). And it's all connected, it all makes sense and every aspect of the game influences your playthrough in one way or another. There is so much in this game, that it's hard to describe to friends when I try to pitch RimWorld to them. 

I have a problem of getting tired with games after a couple of weeks of playing. But I just can't get enough of RimWorld, it's super addictive and exceptionally entertaining, although sometimes the micromanagement can get a bit tiresome. Of course, it has it's flaws, it's not perfect. You will notice a few annoyances and lack of some functionality along the way. But it won't be game breaking. If you like management/simulation/strategy games, have some time to invest in it and want a great story with characters that you will grow attached to very quickly -- then grab it. It's worth it. It's just that type of game that you think about when falling asleep at night and might remember for years to come. Read other reviews. It's not "Overwhelmingly Positive" for nothing, after all. Buy this thing and get immersed into the story of great triumph and miserable failure and just let things happen.

P.S. And don't even get me started on modding... Modding community for RimWorld is one of the best in my opinion. Mods fix almost every issue the game has and if you want even more content, you are welcome to spend hundred more hours on workshop!

131386554.review:
Have you ever wondered if you should give Rimworld a chance? The answer is YES!  This game is one of the best games I have ever played. It has a bit of everything. Management, strategy, tactics and of course story generation. It can be a difficult and frustrating game at times, but that is a part of the game. 

The game is great, because it can be adjusted to your own experience. Are you only interested in creating a cool looking base or are you interested in seeing what it is like to play a wild cannibal tribe? Anything is possible. With all the mods available to this game the only limit is your fantasy. You can also customize how you start the game and your starting characters, and exactly how difficult you want the game to be. I recommend playing it on a difficulty that will challenge you and part of the fun is that sacrifices will have to be made (and I did not mean ritual sacrifices of people although you can do that too). It's not great to see the pawn who built almost everything in your base die, but it does not end the game. Chances are that you find someone else who can rise up to the occasion. 

The game has a lot of depth when it comes to strategy and management. For example you may have the opportunity to get a new colonist with great skills, but you discover that he has the pyromaniac trait. If you live in a colony made out of wood or in a forest it might be too much of a risk to take, however, if you have researched fire foam poppers or have colonists who can spew out fire foam to extinguish fires quickly then perhaps it can be managable. 

A very important part of the game is to handle the mood of your colonists and to make sure that they don't break down. Poor mood can easily lead to the downfall of your colony as the colonists will have multiple breakdowns and not do what they are assigned to. Sometimes they even go on sprees to destroy something and this can really set you back if they destroy something expensive and valuable like that hi-tech research bench you needed to research that piece of armor you want. 

Combat in Rimworld is difficult. It takes a lot of micromanagement and correct positioning of your pawns. Wounded colonists need to be hauled to your medbay and treated there, if the injuries are serious enough they might even need surgery. It starts off easy, but as you expand and increase the wealth of your colony the difficulty increase a lot. The initial raider with a club will be replaced with insect infestations, sieges and mech clusters (with the Royalty DLC). It requires planning and preparation to defeat them or you are guaranteed to fail. Even if you are prepared you will fail sometimes. Especially if your colonists have a breakdown in the middle of a fight because they have been drafted for too long.

The game requires some effort to learn as there are many systems and mechanics in the game, but it is worth it! 

The DLCs are not needed to make the game enjoyable, but they do enhance the experience quite a bit. My least favorite DLC is Royalty, so I would recommend getting this last.

129194632.review:
I get the feeling that Rimworld was WAY more successful than they were initially expecting. Don't get me wrong, it deserves the recognition it has, but I think there's a strong possibility it was one of thoe fluke successes like Valheim. It's a colony sim with a huge amount of depth, customisation and content - but not a brilliant UI. Thankfully the modding community has fixed / added almost anything you could think of, which fixes any potential issues I had, and adds a huge amount of quality of life changes. Mods also very much allow you to "play it your way" rather than adhering to strict difficulty settings, which makes it appeal to an even wider audience.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Nice background music
- Loads of content and events
- Lots of difficulty settings
- Mod support, with a large modding community
- Useful settings for cooking meals like "until you have 5" rather than manually always adding recipes (like ONI)
- Extremely granular rules, if you want, for all kinds of things. There are settings for work schedule, what food people are allowed to eat, what medicine they're allowed, where they can go, which animals are allowed where etc. This is awesome, but can also cause a lot of confusion; like trying to find out why my colonists wouldn't store herbal medicine anywhere. The storage allowed herbal medicine, but turned out it didn't allow "fresh" items.
- You can also set policies for what kind of clothing people are allowed to wear (and set roles for people). It took me a LONG time to realise that. One of my colonists was permanently grumpy because he was wearing a tattered hat. Turns out you have to edit the clothing rules to only allow items with more than 50% hp remaining, otherwise he'll conitnue to complain and wear something that makes him unhappy.
- You can domesticate animals and farm them for produce, meat, leather etc.
- The game is an incredibly detailed simulation. There's so much to mention here. Colonists have individual body parts. The world and the rooms you build have temperature with themodynamics and insulation. There's a roofing mechanic. There are raids. Combat. Colonoists have relationships with each other and get depressed. They have personality quirks. You can capture raiders and take them prisoner, then sell them as slaves or recruit them. The list goes on.
- Animals will breed. You can create an 'auto-slaughter' policy for animals so you can automatically keep your herd sizes down based on the animal growth stage and gender
- When you create your game, you choose where in the world to start. This affects everything on the map you build your colony in, such as growing season, average temperature, land features (hills, mountains, river etc)
- Everything you make from walls to furniture to clothes, can be made out of different materials. The clothes you make have different properties such as thermal insulation and protection depending on the material you make them out of.
- Your colonists and animals generate dirt which needs to be cleaned. The cleanliness score of a room doesn't only affect happiness, but also things like medical procedure success chance

[b]Cons[/b]
Despite any and all of the below, I either found ways around them, learned what I needed to, or found a mod for it.

- Ugly (but you get used to it). Subjective, but this was what put me off the game for years
- Steel is a flammable material
- No Steam achievements
- The UI is really unintuitive. Even after playing for 4 hours I'm never sure where to look for things. There are lots of oddities that can be confusing until you Google them. For example, at one stage I could only make things out of steel instead of wood like I'd been doing so far. Turns out there's a tiny arrow next to the item menu that lets you change the material, and I'd run out of wood
- Without a mod, there's no way to get the camera to follow a colonist to see what they do
- It took me a good 10 hours to work out how to improve "room score" (it's a combination of wealth, size, decor, cleanliness)
The artwork for the colonists walking around your base does not include arms, hands, legs or feet. The system behind them is very intelligent, but the graphical representation means that you can think they're fine, then realise after a few hours that they're missing an arm and need a prosthetic
- The modding community is huge, and that's good because the base game does some basic things really badly. The trade interface is confusing. Colonists will walk into their own traps. Colonists will use super medicine to treat a bruise. Colonists will collect fertilised eggs and eat them when you want to hatch them.
- Rooms are auto-tagged based on what the game thinks they're for. That's fine, but an unexplained mechanic that caused an issue I only found the cause of after a few hours. In my "kitchen, recreation and dining room", colonists were ignoring the table, walking out of the room, outside, into the prisoner room and eating at the table there, because the area I had designed was only tagged as a kitchen.

[b]Let me Google that for you...[/b]
I found it ridiculous how often I had to Google things while I was playing. While the basics are easy enough to grap, I found myself searching for answers to the weirdest things...

rimworld how to butcher animals
rimworld where to store dead animals
rimworld how to get rid of corpses
rimworld how to get cloth
rimworld stop people eating corpses
rimworld how to improve room quality
rimworld assign bed
rimworld fridge temperature
rimworld best size for bedrooms
rimworld stop colonists eating raw meat
rimworld copy and paste buildings
rimworld show stack sizes
rimworld make paths
rimworld move resources
rimworld how to put out fires
rimworld colonist overview
rimworld temperature overlay
rimworld what temperature does rice die at
rimworld why is colonist wearing tattered clothes
rimworld do trees grow back
rimworld what to do with guinea pigs
rimworld what to do with desiccated corpses
rimworld jacket vs duster

So, after forcing myself to play a little more, I saw the mod options! This completely changed my outlook on the game. The stuff you could add tot he game through mods makes the game 100x better. 130373656.review:
What can I say? One of the best colony sims out there. It's been out for a couple of years, and while at first, it seemed to be merely a better looking version of Dwarf Fortress sans the digging, a lot of things were added both by the devs and modders. For example, there are mods to turn your colonists into Jedi or mods like "Prepare Carefully", which may be helpfui for the first few games you play, as you can put together your own colonists and pick what items they crash land with. 

It's a ton of fun, and there are so many things that happen based on world events and the traits of your colonists. Treat them badly, and you may end with a colonist having a mental breakdown, digging out corpses, leaving them on the dinner table,l thereby lowering everyones mood. 

Eventually, you grow used to your colonists and losing one of them due to a random catastrophy sucks. Fortunately, you can save at any point and go back a bit if necessary. 

Here are some things I learned later on, which can be quite helpful when you start out: 
- Not only can you assign your colonists to different duties via the work menu, you can switch to a manual mode there and set up priorities. So if you wanna make sure your chef focuses on cooking your much needed meals, change the priorities. 
- Regarding food - try to make sure to plant raw food early on. Build your kitchen close to the fields, and set up a stockpile room for raw and cooked food close to that kitchen. That way, you can speed up food production, which is essential. 
- You can also determine what is stored in what stockpile area. Once you can build AC units, set up a refrigerated food stockpile room very close to your kitchen. 

I also have started dabbling with the DLCs and will eventually review them. They aren't exactly cheap, but they do add quite a lot of content, like fun new game mechanics. 

Now that Dwarf Fortress has a steam release and a nicer looking, more inviting UI, I will spend some time with that game as well, as it's like one of the ancestors for games like Rimworld, but Rimworld itself will remain a favorite... it's fun and very addictive to set up a new colony and watch the weird curveballs the game throws you. 

Definitely recommended, and if you find it confusing at first, there are great tutorials on YouTube and the aforementioned mod which may give you an easier start to get used to the game. 

Highly recommended... no two playthroughs are the same, and I still love this game.

126858048.review:
I almost lost an entire colony to a Megasloth that I accidentally entombed inside my new walk-in freezer. 

Being the cocky idiot I am, I attempted to kill this giant beast. Only to watch it wipe out my three top colonists, and my dog... With my last colonist unable to fight,  I left her to hide in the barracks hoping the sloth might angrily chew it's way out the colony. Instead it tore through doors and walls in a fit of rage, headed right for the barracks.

That would have been the end of my colony, were it not for the fact earlier I'd sold a prisoner into slavery. Now hear me out, these guys had a freaking panther, and I wanted it. This panther, which I'd largely neglected and was likely to turn feral in a few days, just happened by my new freezer turned slaughterhouse. The Megasloth had met it's match. Realising how close I'd come to losing my entire colony, I knew I needed to take the moral lesson of this story very close to heart. Locking your people in a freezer with a deadly beast is bad, and the trading of exotic wild animals so they fight on your behalf is good.

Rimworld is full of many insightful lessons like these, and will undoubtedly lead to educating you harshly in them. 11/10

130932125.review:
a while ago i decided give cyberpunk a second go. i finished it when it was first released and as we all know, it was a buggy mess with the depth you come to expect from a tiktoker. when i played it recently (1.61 patch) i quickly realized that it still was a buggy mess. just to give you an example, when i called my car i witnessed it going through couple buildings, run over dozens of pedestrians, commit couple war crimes and casually stopping in an undrivable state. character animations, dialogs overlapping.. the list of bugs is huge is what i'm saying. i stopped playing it midway because holy shit, how can this 2 year old game still be in this state.

anyways, i digress. i'll come back to this.

i've been watching ambiguousamphibian's rimworld series for a while not only because they were quite entertaining, because i quickly come to realize that this simplistic looking game had a lot more depth than the games i've played recently. it was intriguing so i picked it up on winter sale.

my first playthrough went well. eventhough i had all the dlc's, i decided to play my first game without them. i installed couple QOL improvement mods in addition to some game changing mods (like combat extended) and gave it a go. at one point i had a message that said "a person living among wild animals has wandered into the area. she's called larky. you can attempt to tame her."

i was like "what? it's a proc gen game so this must be a bug". i captured her then i picked a colonist with high enough social skills to convert her, but when i tried to interact with her i didn't get the option. it took me a while but then it hit me, the message said [b]tame her[/b]. so i picked a colonist with animal taming skills and interacted with her. i literally tamed her, taught her some social manners and she became a valuable member of my colony.

sufficed to say, the feeling i had when i sent my colonists to space was incredibly satisfying.

i'll tell you another story. on my second playthrough i started with 3 colonists (because i'm quite new to this game and i don't have the capability to survive with a single cannibal character in an arctic region). this is my second playthrough afterall. i also added a horse named ping in my starting inventory because i thought it would make my life easier trading with nearby settlements. anyways, time goes on. more colonists join, my base expands. i get attacked by mad beavers, mechanoids and so on. during that time one of my initial colonists, jae forms a bond with ping.

on my third year i realize ping is 31 years old. i don't know how long horses live so i check it's information. turns out the average lifespan of a horse is 30 years. so i make a tough call. i'm gonna release ping to the wild so she can roam freely in her final days. i pick jae for this task, and i set ping free.

couple days later i wondered if she was still in my region so i started looking around the map and there she was, roaming around with a herd. but then.. then i checked her log messages. the message said "jae reminisced about the good time she had with ping and set her free".

as someone who had to put down his 18 year old collie, that fucking message melted my heart. the simple fact that the guys at luden added this tiny detail puts this game in my top 10, easily. cyberpunk can't manage to have this level of personality and detail with it's fucking 70GB size. this 500MB game that runs on a potato can.

i have a friend in my friends list who played this game for over 2000 hours (naber cem?) for a long time i wasn't able to make sense of it, mainly because i didn't know what this game was about but after watching hours of gameplay and then seeing it with my own eyes, i get it.

137889078.review:
In my time playing this game I have done things that many would consider amoral, vile, cruel, and in general, disgusting, although, this is only if one views the story from the side of a witness, they do not see how every moment, every action, creates and solves a new problem, take for instance the actions of cannibalism caused during the cold months, one would simply see this as the result of a mad man being put in a position of too much power, but in reality it was not of my own choice, if I would have sent out hunters to get food, the colonists would have developed frostbite, if they got frostbite, then we didn't have the medicine to properly treat them, this was a lesson learned too late after the deaths of three out of the seven living colonists at the time, and without a way to get food from the surrounding animals without risking the life of the colonists we needed to survive, we had to make do with what we had available, it mattered not the mental states of the people who had to butcher and eat their previous friends, family, and lovers, the survival of the colony was what truly mattered, in times of need any sane person would have committed these actions. Only a fool would let everybody die before making sacrifices, we learned from this experience, and instead of focusing our efforts on researching new shiny tools of destruction, we focused on farming, and keeping the little food we had last as long as possible, eventually this lead to the creation of pemmican, followed by air conditioners, then we realized the reason we couldn’t properly survive the cold months was not because we didn’t have enough food, but because our hunters weren’t equipped to survive the cold outdoors, so we invested our money into the purchasing of two muffalow, which we used to gather wool, both as an item for trade, and as a material for clothing and sandbags. Over the next couple years we realized that the cruel and vile actions we took to survive did not harm us, but helped us in the long run, the results taught us lessons that forced us to look at what we had, what we were to face, and then at how we could survive, we learned that sacrifice was a necessary process, and that even the greatest of warriors must fall in order for more to rise, it is not enough to simply throw a dozen weak sacks of flesh with small guns against hordes of stronger, more durable, and better equipped soldiers. We learned that each life in the colony meant the exact same as the other, we could never afford to keep our best, for if we did it ended up requiring the sacrifice of our adequate, but without the adequate our best fell quick, we learned that even though we may have worshiped some higher power before crashing upon this foreign world, that there is no god that dwells on the RimWorld, there is only death, blood, fear, and dismay, but even in the face of hardship we mustn’t give up, when our allies are taken away from us by raiders we cannot let grief overtake us, if we do not learn and grow from our dead then their lives truly meant nothing, for the true death of a man is a death that is not cared about, it is not when they are forgotten, but when the lessons they taught us are ignored. Yet through the many colonies and allies I have made, and lost, along the way, there seems to always be one thing that stays perfectly consistent. Death is not a threat, it is a wager, you will never be fully guaranteed or denied death, things that should be impossible become reality on the RimWorld, as if everything was stuck upon the verge of insanity. There truly is no right way to survive, whether you be diplomatic, violent, be saints, or morally corrupt devils form the deepest and darkest pits of hell; because in the end, there is always a new beginning, the only thing that dictates your chances of survival are how ready you are to sacrifice, how many of your own you are willing to let die to secure the safety of the colony, and how many corpses you will pile up before you finally learn the lesson they all desperately tried to teach you.
So, can anybody really say that my actions have been immoral? Could a sane man be brought to insane plans and actions due to their own desperate want to survive? I think not, and even if they do, it will not change the fact that I did not regret a single action I took along my path to power, for the power I sought was not that to destroy, but that to protect..
JK the whole thing is basically war crime simulator, go wild, have fun, light a man on fire, use chemical warfare, make child soldiers, and never forget; there are no Geneva conventions in space (:

125019166.review:
Like- Oregon Trail meets Dwarf Fortress... In Spaaaaaaace. Lots of spontaneous and organic challenges to running a colony on a hostile sci-fi world with enemy murder-robots pouring down from space, and giant carnivorous-spiders burrowing up from the ground. If that's not enough, there's also the psychotic drug-addled space pirates, or the ravenous and insane cannibal ravagers. Shades of Firefly, sans a space ship. The sheer scope of what can be done once you have all the expansions is incredible, and you have multiple paths to 'win' the game. If you were stuck in a cabin with no internet for an extended period of time, this is the game for you, as it can entertain for hundreds of hours.

Dislike- The interface requires you to do a lot of reading descriptions on the HUD to get the hang of things. Very very complex. The pawn AI's also are somewhat unreasonable in the level of tinkering and micro-managing with their schedules to make them do common sense things or priority work-- and it really does not need to be. The creator made the default priorities pretty good, the same thought should be extended to making sure that laying marble tile flooring is not be more important than building a security wall, heater, or refrigeration unit, for example. The direct controls when you draft the pawns also need work and polish, because range differences when trying to shoot a distant enemy will divide half or more of your part between firing or walking up to them. The game becomes a very busy schedule-managing game on the high end and feels less like watching a group of people just trying to survive.

But I can say it's worth the price even without the DLCs

EDIT: Dec-04-2022:

1.) These are the Mods i used and why i use em

a.) Smart Farming
-Very helpful in fast changing season areas as well as Random Randy, also to lessen petty jobs for small sowed areas like Hay and Dandelion Animal Feed
b.) Simple FX: Vapor
-Helps me determine cold areas without having to click temperature UI
c.) Character Editor
-This is actually a Cheat, it allows me to make my own Pawn before the start or even during a story
d.) Build from Inventory
-Pawns will take resource from your animal or other pawns as priority but sometimes it's bugged and takes from the furthers resource instead
e.) Smart Medicine
-Pawns will use medicine from other pawns inventory as priority. very useful in 'treat right now' situations
f.) Gear up and Go 
-As the name suggests, your pawns will try to rally and get their battle gear and go to their battle situations but seems useless in late-game scenarios
g.) HugsLib
-tbh i don't know it's use but someone told me to get this and put it on top of my Mod Lists to help with mods
h.) Harmony
-same as HugsLib also no idea what this does, i just took it as a precaution.
i.) Replace Stuff
-it overwries your built items so you dont have to reconstruct or uninstall them, saves a lot of time
j.) RimHud
-Replaces your Pawn HUD (lower left corner) with an easier HUD that gives you all info that you need about that pawn.
k.) Wall Light
-Allows you to place lights on walls, saves space and looks cool (only works on built walls, doesnt work on mountain walls)

That's it for now, will update if i find more cool mods, feel free to comment whatever Mods i can also use

For so many reasons, this is the ultimate simulation game and is one of the greatest games of all time for replayability.

I'm normally very harsh towards games that rely heavily on mods to fix QoL issues. The logic is that your modding community shouldn't have to rescue bad game design. However, Rimworld is just different. Truly, there are many VERY necessary mods that need to be added to the game to preserve your sanity, and for that I think the developers do deserve some amount of criticism. I think the no-brainer changes should be added at some point to the base game so new players shouldn't have to come up with finding the more obscure mods. Like I said though, Rimworld is just different. Rimworld mods are integrated seamlessly into existing saves and that fact alone makes everything forgivable. The mod community is truly the best I've seen on Steam.  

I don't see myself getting bored of this one ever. If you're ever getting bored, you're just not thinking creative enough. This is an all-time great.

130096541.review:
RimWorld is weirdly addictive. I bought it on a whim to see what all the hype is about and I kind of get it, the sandbox is definitely there and theres a lot of emergent gameplay that can be achieved with all the systems, and it just so interesting to watch things unfold no matter what you're doing.

There are things that I dislike about the game, and some of the systems are not communicated super clearly, but when you get a decent grasp on whats on offer here its a great sandbox that you could easily waste hours in. 

Each individual colony consists of a small group of survivors and each survivor has a set of skills and personality traits. They all can get sick, depressed, sleep deprived, overworked, and psycho, so managing everyones needs feels real, and the other systems contribute to this, with there existing systems that allow for recreation, "beauty", art, cleanliness and disease, temperature, resource management, and power management all being major roles in how your colony adapts to the natural challenges they face, as well as other factions that trade, raid, and negotiate with you. There's truly an amazing amount of depth on offer here (I haven't even mentioned every system you engage in) and I urge people who like these kinds of games to really push to give it a try, its a great value. 9/10.

146936074.review:
Bottom Line: One of the best games I've played in 35 years of video gaming. Certainly the best bang for your buck at 1000+ hours of gameplay. 

Base Game: Good
DLC: Royalty: Good (Adds interest options, weapons, armors, a new faction and psy powers)
DLC: Ideology: Very Good (New buildables, ability to customize your faction with religions. Want to be a cannibalistic raiding faction? This is the DLC for you)
DLC: Biotech: Amazing (The best DLC. Combines features from several mods to add in genetic engineering and other fun features.)

Rimworld is an exceptional games that combines the best of games like Dwarf Fortress, The Sims, Theme Hospital, and other colony management games. It is very similar to Prison Architect. Build a colony, research technology, take care of your colony members, expand, trade, and explore the map. Fight off raids, raid other factions, build alliances. Try to survive everything the game's Story Teller engine throws at you while you attempt to escape the planet or don't. You can forgo the quest and simply play until you get bored or get destroyed. The point of the game is the story. No matter how tragic or adventurous, you will remember how you got to the end far more than the ending itself. 

The base game and the DLC not enough for you? The workshop is filled with tons of high quality mods made by talented modders such as Osktar and Bjorn. The Vanilla Expanded series, Alpha Animals, Dinosauria, Arachanphobia, Call of Cthulu, and dozens of faction mods ensure a very varied experience. Mod interaction is exceptional and the Vanilla Genetics Expanded interacts seamlessly with Bioltech's features and some of the animal mods to greatly expand your genetic engineering options. Want a genetically grown Thrumbo/Cthulu abomination? You can have it!

I can't see myself ever getting tired of Rimworld.

145687367.review:
I'll just quickly preface this review with some gushing praise. Rimworld is the single most compelling colony sim I've ever played. I've had it for just over a month and have sunk an absurd amount of hours in, with no sign of slowing.

It's probably also the single best game recommendation I've ever received (thanks Jade)!

I feel there's a lot to be said for emergent, semi-random-story-telling being the future of video games, it's certainly looking that way for me specifically.

It's shocking to me how effortlessly Rimworld acts as a playground for creating the ideal narrative for the player. I've struggled with difficulty for decades in games, and I think Rimworld has my absolute favourite approach to date.

That also extends to thematic and even cosmetic customisation, it's absolutely wild how modular this game becomes when you utilise the steam workshop.

I'm just gonna quickly write out the two random events that happened in my current colony that just instantly locked in this game as my favourite of the year. The two of them are definitely in my top narrative gaming moments of all time:

1. A mere week into my newly formed colony (solo mechanitor start, extreme desert, don't ask). A wanderer shows up and requests to join. She's an absolute meme. The Rimworld community widely considers the trait "Pyromaniac" to among the worst traits for your colonists to possess. I let her stay for 3 reasons. Firstly, I needed the manpower, solo mechanitor is a strong start, but you can easily get taken out, particularly if you get sick. Secondly, I was in the desert. Pyromaniac is still bad there, but it's not like she was gonna be able to burn down my entire map, it was all basically just sand with the occasional rock. Lastly, and most importantly, she shared my actual name, Alex, as well as being asthmatic, which I coincidentally am.

So I gave her a chance, because she was LITERALLY ME.

Over the course of that first year she quickly became one of my best and most reliable colonists. She had a tribal background which made it very easy for her to become a psychic wizard. Her occasional uncontrollable fire starting sprees were annoying, but her timing tended to be pretty manageable. 

One normal day on the rim, we were getting raided as normal by a bunch of weed hippies. She'd been whinging about the tainted flak jacket that I'd been forcing her to wear, but the raids were still extremely manageable given the technological gulf between our colony and the savage weed imp tribe.

So I let her leave the flak jacket at home.

Before the battle, she had one last conversation with one of my other colonists. I have a screenshot of it.

"Alex and Ivy exchanged thoughts about life's many regrets".

Foreboding. Randy Random, it seems, has a tragically cruel sense of irony.

We did away with the tribals with practised efficiency, that's probably giving the squad too much credit, semi-autos and killer robots vs spears and bows is hardly fair, even if it's 4-1 numbers-wise. If anything it had become a little bit routine, hence my hubris.

In the same moment that the tribals had suffered enough casualties to decide that our potatoes weren't worth the hassle, one of their rangers made a final, desperate toss with his pilum. Having now recreated the exact setup after the fact, I know that he had less than a 5-10% chance to land a hit. Given that it was night, it was at the absolute max range of the pilum, and Alex was in decent cover.

I like to imagine it went down like this:

The familiar cacophony of Alex's chain shotgun barks out in defiant fury. Two of the three resulting walls of buckshot introduce themselves unceremoniously to the charging impid. He crumples like a marionette with its strings cut, dead before he hits the floor.

"Ivy, my friend..." Alex spares a glance over he shoulder to the priest guarding her back, charging a fresh magazine. "...I fear I've grown too good at this.." she finishes with a grimace.

"Look!" Ivy responds, "they've thought better of it, they're running!"

"About t-"

Neither Alex sees it coming.

There one moment, gone the next. The Alex that remains (that's me biiiitch) cries out in disbelief.

I don't remember what happened next specifically. Obviously I wanted retribution for my fallen couterpart. The Impids are known as "dustrunners" in-universe, though, due to how fast they are on foot.

Knowing Rimworld, that bastard is probably still out there.

Also, in my blind lust for bloody vindication, I wasn't paying close attention to Alex's corpse. The colony's pet fennec fox, Earbo, was peckish so he waltzed up and ate her head, flak helmet and all. The little fucker.

I FUCKING love this game.

I know above I promised two stories, but this review is way too long, so I'll write the second story, my favourite, as a comment.

The first mutual friend to ask gets this game and the DLC for free, no questions asked, I will comment once this has been claimed. Thanks for reading <3

Bless u Tynan, I'm sure you don't need me to tell you, but you're a artist in a million. PLEASE reach out to Chris Hunt (Lo-Fi games/Kenshi) and u guys can collaborate to make the greatest piece of open ended emergent video game art known to mankind.

It may look simplistic, but the immense amount of content will keep you coming back again and again. Nothing beats the joy of building your first colony from scratch, and the anger when it all comes crashing down because one of your pawn's mental breakdowns causes a heard of boomalope to attack your guinea pig farm. By its self, the game is excellent, but once you add in the vast library of mods, it takes off to Skyrim levels of content and hilarity. It's not for everyone, but if you enjoy Sim management, Logistics, Statistics, RTS, City building, and even a bit of RPG elements, then this is right up your alley. My wife finally starting playing after watching the insanity and she loves it just as much.

144860161.review:
The game bills itself as a storytelling device and it's not wrong. I love watching the strange interactions between my pawns and my husband and I tell each other the tales of what happened during our play of RimWorld that day. 

It's also a great colony manager game. I also love observing them doing their work and trying to figure out how to optimize as I grow my colony.

NOW, that being said. The base game is a little lacking, but the modding community has got you covered. I got hooked playing the base game, then found myself very excited at the options I could add on later.

I still remember the time two of my pawns fell in love extinguishing a raging barn fire.
I still remember when a pawn insulted the doctor who was about to operate on him, causing a fist fight, which the doctor won.
I still remember when my ONLY pawn who could clean was kidnapped, leaving the other two to wallow in their own filth for months until someone crash landed near the base.

Hopefully, you will also create some bizarre stories for yourself.

144375798.review:
You see that play time?
I think that speaks for it self.

The base game is amazing, and I strongly recommend new players start there to see if its for them. As its a niche genre thats not to everyone liking.
If it grabs you like it has me. Then get the DLCs.
Royalty adds a new faction that you can gain noble ranks in and get special requests from them like asking for military or resource support.  Also Psycast power. Being able to raise rock walls for cover or teleporting a raider infront of your turrets are just a few examples.

Ideology simply lets you change the rules of the base game. In the base game cannibalism is always bad (unless they have the canabal trait) with ideology your can make your entire colony like human meat.  Or not mind wearing tainted cloths.  OR you can make it harder.  Like massive mood debuffs for cutting down trees or killing animals. Its a great tool for themeing your colony. Also adds rituals which is fun, you can now have public executions for prisoners or have a dance party to give everyone a mood buff, or have 2 prisoners fight each other for everyones fun.  Cool stuff. But the DLC is mainly about adjusting rules to fit your colony theme to play the game in different ways.

Biotech adds the most in way of features. It adds procreation and children. Adds genetics so you can have different "races" of humans from the fire breathing imp people, the toxic wasters, or even furry wolf people.  But these are just examples for you to get inspired and make your own. Be it before you start your colony or durring a run by collecting and buy genes and make your own super soldier if you want, most people just make cat-girls.  Oh, and theres vampires, immortals that cant die, but must feed!
Another feature it adds is allowing you to now have your own mechanoids!  And they have there own mechanics to making, controlling and calling in "boss" fights to get more special chips you need to research bigger and badder mechs.  I like having a squad of scythers, they tear raiders up!  But the MVP is the cleaner bot.

And yes, after you play all that then you can venture into the land of mods and expand your experience beyond. Rimworld is one of them games that have mods for everything.  Every QoL you can think of and many many more you never thought of, to new features or expanded on existing ones.  And best part is nearly every mod maker incorporates settings you can adjust in game to fine tune the balance do your liking. or cherrypick features of mods you like while turning parts off you dont. Saying your spoiled for choices is an understatement. 

The game is as simple or complex as you want.

TLDR: 10/10, outstanding game! RimWorld is worth every cent and every minute. I absolutely recommend trying it out - there's fun here for just about all types of game enjoyers. :)
---
This is the type of game with immense detail and all sorts of mechanics. You can decide if you prefer a more easygoing story - focused on resource gathering, interactions, and building - or a harsh story with many hardships and more intensity. I usually play MMOs, and games like Stardew Valley, Skyrim, and Subnautica.  RimWorld has already become one of my favorite experiences, with so much depth and freedom in how you play. I learned a lot with my first colony and still feel like I hardly scratched the surface of what's here. 

My first colony was "complete" (they made it to space!!) after ~ 110 hours and I am HOOKED. I can't wait to dive into the dlc next, and mods. :)

143213282.review: To start off, this game is one of the best colony sim/survival games I’ve ever played. The story generator/colony sim aspect just works so well, and the stories that come out of it are sometimes, downright dumb (but in a good way), the game has a way of getting you invested in the story and situations that your characters get themselves into. The relations you can have with the other factions and other characters just elevates the story and experience to a whole other level. The world is your sandbox, and you can do whatever you please, from organ harvesting to making everyone eat each other this has it all, and so much more. Rimworld has sapped many, many hours of my life and I’ve loved every minute of it. To top it all off the music, it’s not what you expect given the graphics, but it is excellent. I could go on forever about this game but just trust me “go give it a shot” it’s worth It.

142210362.review: The single most immersive colony simulation game ever made. While Dwarf Fortress may have more detail and depth, its interface creates a barrier to learning. Rimworld eases this barrier with a much more forgiving interface but similar depth, once you begin to explore Mods. The only flaw to the design is the total lack of "game design" in terms of "levels / goals / quests." It is a truly sandbox experience, and while survival at first takes center stage as the driving purpose/force, it's easy to get lost and wonder "what am I doing?" after awhile. Still, the constant flow of really new and creative mods keeps the game fresh, and a very lively and active streamer community assembles modpacks, themes, and driving goals that help to fill in the gap left by the lack of level/goal/story design. This is a hidden gem that is just waiting for someone to make a really beautiful storytelling framework and create content to explore. Once you're ready, try some of the medieval modpacks with magic to really get blown away at how dynamic and flexible the Rimworld base system is. You won't believe you're playing the same game. DANGEROUSLY addictive and takes huge amounts of time, including customizing your massive mod list before a new run.

Bases can also vary depending on taste, from tribal, medieval, concentration camp (the classic rimworld experience), or some advanced futuristic base. 141943924.review:
Few games combine macro and micro-management as well as RimWorld. People rave endlessly about the atrocities they can commit in the game. And while that's all fun and good, witnessing a story unfold and getting invested in each pawn as an individual is an equally (and likely more) enjoyable experience.

If you're the kind of player who just wants to sit back and build a thriving colony, you can do that. If you're a challenge seeker (or a glutton for punishment), you can and will be tested. While by default the in-game events are "weighted-random", the player can tailor the game to achieve their own preferred experience. Mods can further customization on all fronts (especially QoL) and the workshop community is going strong.

Pick up RimWorld and prepare to sink between 3 and 30 hours a day on your conquest to stay ahead of the Storyteller. Fulfill every trade, complete every quest, and if someone raids your colony, raid them back!

I'mma be honest, I went into Rimworld expecting it to not be something I enjoyed at all. I've seen tons about it, and friends raving about the game, and it just never seemed like something I liked remotely.

Holy shit was I wrong.
This game is honestly surprisingly chill, and strategic. It's an RTS base builder where you can rarely ever directly command your little pawns, and it's oddly nice. Watching your little colonists waddling around and performing actions for you, just trying to survive via any means...

Try it out, maybe you'll find out you like it like I have.

141606550.review:
This is one of those games where it may take you a couple of days to get acquainted with the mechanics, how everything works, etc, but if you spend the time to do so, it's simply one of the best games out there.

When I first started it, deep into the pandemic, I literally spent around 50+ hours on my tutorial colony within the first 3 days. I was sucked in. I ended up sinking nearly 500+ hours into that first tutorial colony, and another 500 exploring many other scenarios, with my favorites lasting many, many decades.

I love their approach to storytelling and the way they achieve this, with thing being as shallow or as deep as you want it to be.

With every patch and DLC, they seem very mindful about how they want the game to be played, providing excellent patch notes and reasoning for each addition and change.

This is one of those games where, like Minecraft, I may not play it everyday anymore, but I'll play the crap out of it whenever there's a new major patch / DLC  and/or play it when I suddenly get the seasonal to bi-annual crave to jump in again, remaining as one of my favorite games for the foreseeable future.

141543732.review:
I'm not even sure where to start with Rimworld. 

This game has so many wild variables and ways to play that it's almost overwhelming at times. But man, if you get super into this and really kinda let things happen in the game, it's incredible. 

The fact that I can say to my girlfriend "Oh today on Rimworld, our llama who has dementia wandered out of the pen and pissed off a herd of elephants who then rampaged through my village while one of us was having our ceremony to become a cool noble space knight, and destroyed our weed farm in the process" is enough to put this game in my top ten favorite games any day. 

The UI can be clunky at times, and it's a lot to look at the first time you boot it up. It's got little tricks you eventually learn throughout playing, like holding down X and clicking walls you want to delete, or linking storage settings in big store rooms for easier controlling what goes in and out of that room. At times it can be very micromanagey, and the UI doesn't help a ton with that micromanaging, but once you get down the game it's easy, and you can set and forget a lot of stuff. 

You can play this game a lot of different ways. I started off my little colony on peaceful mode and just kinda vibed, making the communist utopia of my dreams, completed with required weed smoking everyday at breakfast at a big dinner table in the middle of the communal garden. My friend plays his as a violent, slave owning warlord who burns everything to the ground. I've had other friends play super zealous paladin people. It's wild. So much of the game depends on how you initially set it up, Peaceful is very fun, but so is ultra hard everything kills you mode. It just depends on what you're feeling, but this game has something for everyone I believe. 

The game is nothing crazy to look at. It doesn't have stunning graphics, but if you're into this type of game I'm sure you're used to games not looking like AAA titles. That's not why we're here in this section of steam lol.

Anyway, if you've played games like Dwarf Fortress or Space Haven, or any other story generator colony game, this is the daddy of them all. and I mean that in the very sexy way. Also please for the love of god mod this game. There's so many banger mods out there. 

Seriously. The game is good on it's own. But the game becomes WAY better with mods.

okay anyway buy this game if you want a game that literally anything can happen thanks luv u bye
