139303155.review:
RimWorld is a fantastic game that seamlessly balances intricacy and simplicity, creating a wonderfully immersive and addicting experience. The tutorial is a prominent game aspect, providing newbies with a smooth learning curve while enabling experienced players to get straight into the action. The many modifications available make the game even more adaptable and adapted to individual tastes.

One of the game's most vital points is its ability to tell unique and compelling tales. Each replay provides infinite choices, enabling players to create their own stories. Even little decisions' unpredictable nature and repercussions offer a fascinating and immersive experience.


The reality of RimWorld is both a benefit and a disadvantage. While this adds complexity and excitement, it also means that even little errors may have serious repercussions. A little rat scratch might end your most loved colonists, introducing a tremendous degree of struggle and decision-making. It keeps players on their toes and reminds them that survival is never assured.

The attention to detail in the game is astounding, with sophisticated mechanisms and systems that integrate perfectly. RimWorld has a wide range of gameplay components to keep you busy for hours, from managing resources and building your colony to defending against invaders and exploring the environment.

The only slight disadvantage is that the initial allure may wear off after a time, mainly if you develop a thriving colony. This is easily alleviated by pausing and returning to the game later, as the addictive nature of RimWorld will undoubtedly lure you back in.

139299400.review: im now on a no fly list

139171848.review:
Years ago, I played a lot of Minecraft in creative mode, making empty cities and RP-ing. Eventually I got bored, so I played many different city builders. None of them really scratched the itch, rarely exceeding 20 hours of play-time. 

I then saw a play-through of Rimworld, and I was immediately enamored. It looked like you could do everything you can think of - grow crops, design the perfect village, brew beer, breed polar bears, and even turn your people into vat-grown fire-worshiping drug-addled cyborg cannibals. I saw a tremendous amounts of room for RP and tons of challenging and complex decision making. 

So I booted up the game, played the tutorial, and continued the run. Not knowing much about the game, I ordered my colonists to make a bunch of rooms, prioritize researching drug production, and eat some foraged berries. I quickly realized this game is incredibly complex as my electrical components deteriorated outside, my deer kills rotted, and my colonists hated their dirty barracks and each-other. I spent alot of time studying the game UI, getting a feel for my colony's work load through trial and error, and meticulously configuring stockpiles. More challenges faced me as my crops and colonists felt the effects of winter, got permanent injuries to social fights and bandit raids, and even faced deaths to malaria. 

Before I knew it, I had 50 hours in this game - my colony consisted of nearly 15 people, we had incredible security in wealth/arms/food, and I eventually sent my original three colonists into space - with alot of challenges along the way. 

I realized I only scratched the surface of this game as I perused the wiki for efficient ways to run the colony, installed all of the DLC content, and downloaded a myriad of mods. I played about a dozen more runs, all of them different due to the colonists, the DLC and mod parameters, and even the starting biomes and landforms. 

In conclusion, this is THE game if you are looking for a colony sim/city builder/RP box. After climbing over the initial learning curve, you will find yourself appreciating the game's incredible depth and you will always be discovering different ways to play and interesting things to do. You can configure nearly every parameter for a big challenge or a silly creative run. Even after hundreds of play time, you will find that there is a mod for EVERYTHING due to the game's incredible modability to make your next run interesting.

The game has fantastic replayability. allows for lots of creativity and there are so many different things you can pursue and manipulate that it ends up being incredibly fun for a very long time. The challenge to survive is entertaining, but if your a newer or more casual player you can pick a more forgiving storyteller and lower the difficulty whenever you like, or you can do what i enjoy and ramp up the difficulty with randy as the story teller and see what the game throws at you. The developers are active and the community is as healthy as a group of heartless psychopaths can be so i definitely recommend giving it a whirl. Hope you all enjoy it as much as i have

135355477.review: Since i recently hit 500 hours on the game i thought i should finally make a review on it. First off it is a slow moving game and graphically somewhat hideous so if looks are something you care much about then you probably shouldn't get it. But if you care more about the incredibly unique brutal and hilarious story aspect of the game then buy it immediately. You can basically have whatever type of colony you want too, Expample: i recently owned 2 slaves (in game) and they tried to rebel so i beat one of them to death in "self defence" and the survivor was punished via chopping off her nose and making her eat it. On the other hand i've had a colony that was a peaceful thriving village with farms and happy children. So obviously there are many different sides to rimworld which is just one of the reasons it's so amazing and more significantly, so detailed and in a way insanely realistic. One example of the sheer detail in this game is the injuries, your colinists or "pawns" can suffer from lacerations, cuts, bruises, bullet wounds of different calibers and more. Now for my last point which is mods. The modding is extensive in rimworld and the DLC's also add so much to the game (biotech is the best DLC by far) but the mods are super easy to install, literally one button in the steam workshop. The essentials that i reccomend the most are all of the Vanilla Expanded mods by Oscar Pocthki or smtn like that , along with this is the combat extended mods and also the more injuries mod but i dont reccomend it when you're a new player. Anyways you should immediatley but please please for the love of god watch a tutorial because without it you'll be clueless and get r@ped by the storyteller, good luck

An exhilarating and infuriating mix of colony survival, sci-fi, military strategy and The Sims; in RimWorld you are tasked with managing the relationships of your beloved pawns while fighting hordes of unforgiving and impenetrable automatons.

RimWorld has a special place in my heart, being one of my most played games on Steam and my favourite colony-simulation game possibly ever, I wholeheartedly recommend it for anyone thinking about buying it (though, wait for a sale), not only because of the fun and (rarely) calm, satisfying gameplay, but just due to the sheer, unbelievable variety and quality in the modding scene of this game, I can't explain just how much stuff you can find, and thanks to some dear pals I've been able to make my owns mods as well. The giant community of crazed cannibals that surrounds this game is truly unique, and I couldn't ask for more, I've made many friends thanks to this game.

Addendum: The DLCs are wonderful packs of content as well, Biotech and Royalty add a lot of new toys to the game, while Ideology functionally changes the gameplay, I'd personally recommend all 3.

9.5/10 (.5 points deducted because of the awful mech designs of the Biotech DLC.)

Nation building is a skill best learned under the pressures of war, famine, insurrection and death as my predecessors will attest. Rimworld has provided me with the opportunity to build these concrete skills to match my zeal for creating a prosperous nation, all in a controlled virtual environment that adequately simulated such pressures. 133470925.review:
RimWorld is a phenomenal game that combines strategy, simulation, and storytelling in a way that keeps you engaged for hours on end. As a player, you're tasked with managing a group of survivors who have crash-landed on a harsh and unforgiving planet. From there, you'll need to build a base, gather resources, research new technologies, and fend off threats ranging from raiders to wild animals to natural disasters.

One of the things that sets RimWorld apart from other games in its genre is the sheer depth and complexity of its systems. Every colonist has their own unique skills, traits, and quirks that can affect their performance and interactions with others. Additionally, the game features a detailed health and injury system, which adds an extra layer of challenge and realism.

Despite its difficulty, RimWorld is also incredibly rewarding. There's nothing quite like watching your colony grow and thrive, or seeing a group of colonists overcome seemingly insurmountable odds to survive. And because the game is procedurally generated, each playthrough is different, which means you'll never run out of new challenges to tackle.

Overall, I would highly recommend RimWorld to anyone who enjoys strategy or simulation games. Its deep systems, engaging storytelling, and rewarding gameplay make it a must-play title for fans of the genre.

132759163.review:
RimWorld - a game that is equal parts hilarious and brutal, created by Tynan Sylvester and released by Ludeon Studios. It's a game that makes you both laugh and cry as you guide your colony of hapless survivors through the perils of a hostile, procedurally generated planet.

As you start the game, you're greeted with a set of colonists who are as flawed as they come. One has a bad back, another is an insomniac, and yet another is a cannibal. It's your job to keep them alive, despite the game throwing every curveball it can at you. Maybe your colony is hit by a toxic fallout, or a pack of manhunting squirrels. Or perhaps a raider faction decides they want what you have and attack your colony. Either way, you're in for a wild ride.

But RimWorld isn't just about managing your colony's survival. It's also about the stories that emerge as you play. Maybe your bionic-limbed colonist falls in love with the blind, pacifist herbalist. Or perhaps your colony is visited by a group of traders who turn out to be slavers, leading to an epic battle for the freedom of your fellow colonists. The sheer variety of events that can occur is staggering, making each playthrough feel unique and fresh.

One of the most enjoyable parts of RimWorld is the ability to mod the game to your heart's content. From adding new items and events to creating your own scenarios, the modding community for RimWorld is robust and active. It's always exciting to see what new mods come out, and how they can change the game in unexpected ways.

In conclusion, RimWorld is a game that is both funny and heart-wrenching, and never fails to keep you on your toes. Its unique mix of survival, storytelling, and modding possibilities make it a game that you can play for hours and still find something new to discover. If you're looking for a game that is both challenging and entertaining, RimWorld is definitely worth a try. Just be prepared to lose a few colonists along the way.

132395637.review:
TLDR: very addicting, has only a few issues that can be frustrating to deal with	

	RimWorld is my favorite colony simulator game, it has a perfect blend of taking care of your people, while managing them and your resources. You can make your own choices in any way you want to, and it’s incredibly satisfying to see the progress you make. While there is an end to the game, you can take your time as there is no pressure to complete it. There is plenty of content in the base game without DLC’s and I thoroughly enjoyed most of the hours I played without them.

	It should be noted that the beginning of the game is very slow and quite boring. When you start a game it eases you into it, so you can learn how to play without being overwhelmed. I knew that I would be able to enjoy the game later on, but it still took me 3-4 attempts to push through the beginning. It’s a good thing I did, because once the game started to pick up speed, it became addicting. Players should keep this in mind when they play for the first time.

	Analytical people will especially enjoy this game as later in the game, you will find things you can consistently improve in. For example, things like making specific paths to reduce walk time and increase productivity. You can also improve by carefully making schedules and work for each person to do by assigning a few people to build things, a few to work with plants, and some to work with animals. Or if you have a colonist with no skills, make them clean the colony so no one else has to. Having a colonist join and re-shaping the colonist’s work is immensely satisfying when you see them becoming increasingly efficient. 

	There is Rimworld meme about how you should never ask what awful things people who play it do on there, which makes sense because you can do (almost) anything you could think of, no matter how awful. Prisoners can be set free to gain reputation with their faction, or you can recruit them to yours; but what if you hate everyone and don’t need their skills? Well then you can harvest their organs to be sold to traders. Worried that they’ll try to escape? Replace their legs with wooden pegs so they can’t run. Is a colonist being mean to everyone by saying rude things? Remove their tongue so they can’t speak. You can grow “smokeleaf” and “psychoid” plants to be processed into drugs and sell them, buy and sell slaves, or even psychologically torture people who have wronged you. In this game, morality becomes frivolous to progress the colony. This is what makes Rimworld so engaging and unique from other games in this genre. 

	Even though there’s so many good things about Rimworld, every game has its faults; this is no exception. Some issues I have with the game are subjective, but I’ve seen most of them mentioned before pretty much everywhere I look in this context.

	Later in the game you’ll notice a lot of lag as the game runs on only a single core of your CPU. Late game colonies will become insufferable and eventually impossible to play because of the performance. You’ll notice this when there’s a lot on the screen such as being raided or invading other colonies. As you do these things the game will grind to less than 10fps, and sometimes will practically become a slideshow. It becomes discouraging to play as sometimes the game will only run fine for a few moments, and then go back to the low quality performance, which frustrating to say the least. 

	The game is also full of tiny aspects that will be annoying when you play. Usually these relate to “realistic” behavior. Although realism isn’t necessary in games, it can become annoying when something happens that wouldn’t or is unlikely to happen in real life. This only applies to small, but prevalent behaviors in how the characters act.

	Another issue I have with the game is that sending colonists on caravans somewhere outside the colony isn’t as valuable as having them inside the colony to complete objectives; Especially early-game as you only have a limited amount of people, so if you send your builder out, you can’t build anything efficiently until they return. Additionally, there really isn’t any reason to leave the colony until much later. The only thing you’ll really leave the colony for is to trade with other factions. 

	Rimworld has a huge modding community, so much so that it’s unlikely you’ll see players running the game without mods. This is due to the previous things I’ve mentioned, but if it’s not the case of fixing something that you don’t like, then it’s to add content in the game, some of which fitting so well, that its surprising that it’s not already there in the first place. You can go as far as to say it’s difficult to play without some of them. 

	Overall, the problems I have are massively outweighed by the positive aspects, but unfortunately still do exist in the game, and can be impossible to ignore. Every game has its issues, but nevertheless, Rimworld will steal a lot of time from you if you let it. Entire days will be lost to watching colonists interact, improving absolutely everything, trading, and exploring. I love this game with all my heart, and I hope other games follow in its footsteps.

131895090.review:
IMBD 8/10 Drama, Action, Heroic Story


When I started to play a new game we were 3 colonists with raiding goals till a trader from 6th HellWalkers shows up. Trader was a real cyborg, a human with all bionics parts and things. He had last technology armor and weapon as well. When I checked his goods there were 20k silver,150 components, 350 medicine, lots of power armor, etc. My inner raider came up when I saw the items and I started to make a plan. The plan was simple, we had a guest from a high-tech colony and he had power armor and bionics as well he would fight with the trader 1-1 and the other colonist would attack him with their revolver and bolt action rifles. We started to act on our plan everything was perfect at the beginning but there were 2 things we did not predict… first thing the trader had 3 polar bears in their convoy, and the second thing the guest we were trusting started to run away after he killed the trader. We had no chance to win against 3 polar bears with ranged weapons. Bears catch our colony leader and bite off his head and they started running away with carrier buffalos. At the end of the day, we did not get anything but a failed quest, got 2 high-tech hostiles and a dead leader. Our morals were bottom and I thought it was the end but we did not surrender! I knew that was a continue-or-die situation. I armed all of the people in my colony I even armed a refugee child and her mother with a kitchen knife in order to hold the line. I was hopelessly watching my colony be kidnapped by savages then my savior arrived... MAN IN BLACK! He killed the guy who was carrying my colony leader and put our leader on a bed and tended him. I did not give up I healed our wounds and started to rebuild our base, the only thing that delaying our rebuild was fucking mental of our leader. He was getting mental disorders every 3 days. It was getting hard and harder to keep him under control. Then another raid alert showed up this time there was only one man yes he was the guest himself that I used to kill the first trader. He came up to take his revenge. Thanks to our mental statement we couldn't finish building walls around the base. Mf was walking with %250 efficiency and he had a fucking chainsaw and a shield as well. He butchered and downed the man in black and downed my leader and kidnapped the man in black and ran to the horizon. On a rainy day our leader once again lying on the ground witnessed the kidnapping of his friend, asking for help... Once again I thought this is the end then a half-pig half-human refugee came up to my colony and rescued our leader and tended his wounds. There is still hope for us to recover but then our leader could not hold anymore and he went into a coma statement, he ain't waking up or eating, only breathing in the bed. After 5 days in coma, he woke up and started to work but this time big refugee could not hold it and started gazing around the base. 131779667.review:
There’s a game that you can’t win, you can’t break even, and you can’t even get out. No, I am not talking about the laws of thermodynamics. I am talking about Rimworld. It’s a Pandora's box that I can’t get out of.
Sure, you can win the game, at a high cost of course. The charm of the game is tactically managing resources and human talents. On paper, it would make sense to allocate more resources to unskilled pawns with greedy or jealous traits who you are promoting with higher titles while ordering mentally stable pawns working overtime. Under this logic, a useless pawn would spend most of its time meditating in an 80 square throne room with lavish meal in its inventory while a large population lives in a 2X2 square single bed room and only allowed simple meals and herbal medicine. Needless to say, the peasant pawns would be assigned to melee attack in the front line while the precious titled pawns are standing in the safe zone and trying to make history.
But what if, I wonder, Wiking’s happiness theory and Bregman’s human kindness theory could work in this hush “reality” (i.e., starve to survive in Randy)? Would a free, high quality healthcare system survive in this simulation game? How about democracy and a check-and-balances system? I decided to prioritize happiness (mood level) above technology progress and colony wealth as a social experiment. Yes, I know this is not a cutesy game like Stardew Valley or Animal Crossing. (I mean… have you checked the Ideology DLS?) But I was just curious what if I only assign 6 hours of working hours with 3 hours of recreation hours so that they can spend them in extremely impressive recreation room; allow everyone - including guest refugees - glitter medicine; rather promoting one pawn to the highest title but spreading honors equally among 3 pawns according to how popular they are among the colonists?
Sure, in the end, it’s a happy and well-defend colony. But guess what, it’s Randy; you can’t break even. You can survive many raids, man/woman hunting packs, and mech clusters, but colonists would still suffer from the inevitable curse of aging (“Birthday: bad back/ dementia”) and heartbreaks. Everyone is happy? Great! But you still can’t prevent love rejections, affairs, and divorces among the colonists. And yes, the Royal DLS added many new technologies to fix these problems, even a serum to revive a dead colonist. But at what cost? Sooner or later, something bigger - from external or internal factors- will rise. The only existing is pack up and leave this colony that you have spent hours to build.
Then why am I still playing it? Because I can’t get out of this Pandora’s box.

131631016.review:
Positive Review:
Rimworld is the ultimate survival game that will make you feel like a real-life MacGyver. The game's sci-fi setting is out of this world, you'll be building your colony on a distant planet, and all the while, you'll be thinking "I could build a rocket and go back home, but where's the fun in that?" The game's mechanics are so deep you'll feel like you're playing a game of chess against yourself. The game's characters are so diverse, you'll want to adopt them all, like a farmer with too many pigs. And the game's modding support is so good, you'll start to question your own reality.

Negative Review:
Rimworld is the ultimate time-suck of a game! The game's sci-fi setting is so captivating you'll forget to eat, sleep and shower. The game's mechanics are so complex, you'll need a PhD to understand them. The game's characters are so diverse, you'll start to question your own sanity. And the game's modding support is so good, you'll start to question the game's reality. You'll lose all your friends, your job, and your sanity but, who needs them when you have Rimworld?

Conclusion:
Rimworld is a great game for those who enjoy survival and strategy games and don't mind losing track of time. If you're looking for a game that will make you lose touch with reality, this is the perfect game for you! But if you're looking for a casual game, you might want to look for another option, this game can be really time-consuming and complex.

131561050.review:
I'm finally writing a review, after over 200 hours. Easily one of my favourite video games that I've ever played, for what that's worth. However I will say that I do think this game requires at least the Royalty DLC to be truly awesome. Without quests, it can tend to get sort of dull if you manage to keep a colony alive for a long time. Or, maybe it's better to say you might start to feel a bit aimless without the randomised guidance of quests (and the "main" win-the-game ones). With that being said, I'll just list off some things I love and dont love about the game as they come to me.

Things I love:
- Customisation - You can literally do whatever you want. Make a cannibal cult, make the space police, make a horrible, inefficient stone age tribe and see what idiocy they do.
- Mods - You can easily just click on cool looking mods on the Steam Workshop. I like the ones that let you fine-tune stuff like the Prepare Carefully mod. It lets you make your own custom characters/pawns instead of hitting the "randomise" button 100 times until you get someone with a cool combo of stats and traits.
- Difficulty - The game is hard. Even on the baby mode, until you learn how stuff works, you will kill everyone in your colony repeatedly, until you learn how to prevent food poisoning, or to stop your pawns from putting rotting corpses in your fridge. Once you learn the mechanics and 'rules' you can then fine-tune the difficulty however you want. The game by default lets you play with %'s for anything from difficulty of threats, extremes in temperatures or climate, how often threats appear, and even lets you change who the "storyteller" is at any time. Different AI that have a different style. One gradually increases difficulty and causes threats at set intervals, one gives huge downtime between attacks but rapidly increases strength, and one is complete random, each saving any changes or parameters you set at the beginning.
- Story - This game has fairly bare bones when it comes to story. Either you're a tribe native to the planet or you've crashed from space and are trying to escape this Rimworld to get back to civilisation. But it's because of the "lack" of a hard narrative that it's storytelling is so good. The stuff your pawns do (on their own or by your mind control) forms a story itself. I had a woman marry and divorce three men, only to have two of the exes get killed, which caused her psyche to snap, and she started a fist fight with her current husband and killing him. It's often morbid, but always silly and entertaining.
- Morality - You can be as mean or nice as you want to your little imaginary video game people! Give them lush bedrooms and huge dining halls, throne rooms for your leaders and hosting great banquets and celebrations, regularly getting "Inspirations" that vastly increase one of your pawns kills for a few days. But it will cost you extremely in planning, materials, and sacrifice. A gaudy colony is a sight to behold because you know it went through a few collapses to get there. Or, you can laugh at your people as you cram them into tiny barracks and tell them to sleep on the dirt even though you've told them to build beds in there. You'll regularly be getting mental breaks where they'll do anything from attacking eachother, setting buildings on fire, or just being sad and hiding in their room for a day, refusing to eat or do anything. But think of all the extra money and resources you'll have. And the guns, goodness the guns you can buy if you neglect amenities!!

Things I dont love:
- learning curve - It's kinda hard to start playing. There is a fairly good tutorial that does teach you most of what is required to understand. But, there are so many basic steps even when just starting a new colony that you'll regularly forget one or two critical steps. Like, forgetting to tell anyone that they're allowed to cook, and then watch in maddened confusion when they REFUSE to eat anything or make new meals, so everybody ends up eating raw meat and going on mental breaks because of it. 
- powergaming - This game is advertised as a Story Generator. It is not meant to be beaten, and it is extremely difficult to get to the end added by the Royalty DLC (returning to space to go home). As fun as it is to try and save-scum the crap out of this game, and min/max every pawn's skills and traits, the game is best when you let the catastrophes win. That's not how I play games (or, even this game) but sometimes I cant help but laugh when one of my pawns burns down the kitchen and freezer because someone else's bedroom looks nicer than theirs. Set your expectations, or steel yourself to try and overcome a game that will eventually try to break you. For instance, super late game you'll be facing full-scale invasions by upwards of 200 enemies with rocket launchers, miniguns, etc, while your colony of 5-20 hand picked pawns just do whatever they can to prevent death.

I honestly had to sit and think for a bit to decide what to say against the game. Royalty and Ideology are fantastic, and honestly help make the game great instead of fine to good. I know that sounds rough, but it's my opinion. I still think it's worth buying the base game due to mods, but it easily jumps to industry shaping levels of good with the DLC's. I don't own Biotech yet but I'll be getting it during the next sale for sure.

I guess what I'm saying is; When your pawns relatives are in enemy raiding parties, kill them first and then turn their skin into cowboy hats and force your pawns to wear their parents as a hat so that they always get a positive mood bonus for being reminded of their loved ones (that they killed [They'll get over it]). 

[b] 11/10, would cannibalise again. [/b]

131501967.review:
Rimworld, 

my favorite game of all time, my hours will show you, especially if we are friends are steam, that they constantly go up. personally, this game has ended relationships, brought new friendships, made me a less sociable person even though im out going,  made me panic and also shred real tears of lose. I've only "beaten" the game ONCE out of all my hours. my next highest game is around 2,000 hours. the mods are great and supporting the developer is amazing but mods are the lifeblood of this game, without them and all the wonderful mods, i think this game wouldn't have as much of an emotional feeling. you pick a scenarios or edit it yourself, start off with three pawns (colonists) or just one. gradually expanding a base thats your home, hunting deer for food, making crops to feed yourself, mining precious ores to smelt,  and eventually getting weapons and armor. each colonist feels different from one another,  some are snotty people who cant be trusted to do anything and the others are the bread and butter of your colony who cant be allowed to die. he DLC's allow you to make a religion, make babies, or even become a royal to a crumbling empire that can call in favors. im honeslty talking a fraction of each DLC, please review them.  in your religion you can be drug users or my favorite mount crusades killing or converting all in your path. making babies makes you be able to produce more colonists without having to result in capturing prisoners, cannon fodder for warfare or a means to an end? you decide. becoming a royal lets you call on special favors that saves your colonists at certain times. food, luxury,  or material to expand your ever-consuming base or perhaps more soldiers to defend against the horrors of insects or raiders? almost whatever you can imagine can be put into this game with the right mods or personal creativity of your stories. story tellers are there pushing your colonists along with gifts, good weather, or even a tornado that destroys this seasons of grain. making yourself, your own base's story teller is a win-win, which ill get to below.

personally i like to build a base, make a religion, make sure my colonists are making new blood (babies) to die in future wars for organs, wealth, and even prisoners to later recruit in an never ending cycle of blood.  without trying to touch the game, once i have the primary base finished with the storage locations created and with minimal input from myself, i let the game run in the background of real life work. trusting what i did right; the player, storyteller, god, will allow my colony to thrive and survive. losses are acceptable due to raids, stupid mood swings where a colonist decides to destroy HE shells, etc .some colonists just simply shouldn't live and have more use as chairs or leather hats. if i notice a problem, ill play god (developer mode) and revive a colonist who had their head blown off and resurrect them, taking a role of a storyteller that the colony make some pact with an unseen power to bring them back to life, who eventually down the lines requires a child sacrifce.  or ill spawn some suicide vests (a mod i love) that i make slaves wear to march into the middle of a raid to simply kill and blow up the enemy. once or even if prisoners are taken, thanks to ideology DLC, ill make them fight to the death to win my love, those that win become either esteemed slaves with normal weapons or new colonists, remember raiders aren't humans. those that lose, are sent into combat because i cannot feed them and to make them die would prevent a starvation amongst my more valuable colonist or are turned into clothes and chairs.  thanks to Biotech, i can make my own genes, allowing my colonists to become better killers but have to take drugs that my ideology permits or hates.i can make babies that turn into super soldiers or just slave labour and later discarded if their uses aren't what im needing. i can make vat grown colonists who in time will be sent to defend the colony against the enemy and cant be called upon to grow food or even make a meal. if my colonists all die, eventually (again with a mod) one random stranger might join and make the cycle a new.  

becoming the storyteller of Rimworld keeps your interest in the game. 

on a serious note: the DLC's are crucial if you have some experience in the game already. Rimworld's DLCs dont go on sale much (even Rimworld itself doesn't) and if you can afford it, get it. if you cant afford the DLCs that do add some cool content, go with mods.  i personal like Biotech and Ideology, than i recommend the mods that the very active community are giving out. the change the game in so many ways. id pay all of the mod developers for them. you also have to come up with your own stories to make the game fun.  for example why was Jamie such an expendable person? because she wouldn't do dumb labor or produce children to keep your colony up to strength. for the same reason John was just a meat shield in times of raiding or Zax was assent that couldn't be allowed to die because of his great political ability or genes that i needed to produce more soldiers. the possibilities are endless.

Rimworld is a learning experience. play with developer mod until you get it right. like i said above, i only beat the game ONCE, i didn't have to, but after i beat it after 500 hours i finally got mods that drastically changed my game where i had to relearn it. you also don't have to become the killing machine colony like i talked about, that's how i play the game (i insanely like Warhammer 40,000 and taken a lot from the novels, i even have a quote tattoed to me, To partake in our crusade, is to be immortal) you could create a colony of peaceful non-combatants who desire to become high all the time. seriously with the right amount of story playing, base building, colony management, the possibilities are almost endless.

 i love Rimworld, ill play it forever and ever until i'm dead. the game has even saved my life, i have often decided to play it drunk and skip parties that i'd have driven to and possibly crashed and died. honestly it has happened more than once. when my girlfriend broke up with me i played the game, it made me sane again.  the development team is amazing, the people adding mods are amazing, it just comes down to you playing it. if the game doesn't make you happy, add me as a friend on steam and ill send you paragraphs on why you should push on. in fact there is a mod where you could play multiplayer. Rimworld will be my favorite game ever made no matter if the developers randomly decided to stop developing it. of course, any game can burn you out, but Rimworld has mods. 

to think i only talked about a little of the game to write this review. just don't forgot to make tables. 

(i do not have the best grammar and spelling mistakes are bound to happen, please excuse.)

130946991.review:
The colony begins small. Three people crash land in a savage and unforgiving land with no hope for rescue. They manage to build a small camp for themselves, but amidst their desperate daily struggle to adapt, they're beset upon by raiders; barely surviving the conflict, they cling to their civility and humanity. They treat the surviving raider, save him from his harrowing withdrawal and invite him to stay. Danny, the massive former pirate swears to repay their generosity someday.

Weeks become months and their first winter arrives. They're woefully unprepared. Their hunting skills are poor, and the crops wither. Just as they begin work on a greenhouse, the neighbouring savages mount a surprise assault. Shots are fired at the hapless survivors, molotov flames engulf their huts and storehouses, burning nearly all of their belongings to the ground; yet somehow they survive the day.

Their choices are to commit cannibalism or starve. Each make the same grim choice. Every bite changes them; chipping away at what little remained of their humanity, and they decide to survive no matter how heartless they'd need to be in the days ahead.

Travellers arrive now and again with meager items to trade and barter, only to be taken captive and put to work in labour camps. Any sign of rebellion is met with the scalpel. Our survivors learned that there are immense profits to be earned from healthy organs.

They entrench themselves in a mountain they'd quarried out through brutal prison labor. With the money from the organ trade, they establish a powerful base of operations, and finally they feet safe. The feeling doesn't last. There is no God; the rim punishes the strong and meek alike.

In the deepest cavern of the mountain, they'd furnished a research station, and a production line for clothing and weaponry. The group spend the majority of their time here while the prisoners pay in sweat or blood.

Without warning, the ground burst open and insectoid abominations spring forth with pincers and scythe like appendages slashing at any human in sight.

Caught completely unawares, they scramble for dear life, but Danny screams at everyone to make for the door. The leader saw through bloodshot eyes that Danny had grabbed several grenades and ran headlong into the creatures and shut the door behind him.

The ensuing explosion shook the mountain. The research room became a tinderbox, and everything inside turned to ashes.

It took days for the shock to wear off. The prisoners were starving and near revolt. The survivors sat around a fire, and the leader spoke first. He said that in their final conversation before the attack, Danny spoke of his regrets. It pained him to see how the kindhearted people who saved his life had become so cruel, but he didn't know how steer them back.

The survivors agreed then, that they'd again change course. They'd end their organ trade, and they'd strive to be good, in Danny's memory.
They fed and tended the prisoners and gave them the option to leave or stay. If they stayed, they'd be treated as equals, and reparations would be made for their treatment.

Two of the dozen prisoners left, swearing their revenge. Now a group of thirteen entering into spring they set to work on rebuilding.

They spent two years mending their relationships with their neighbors. At first, gifts of reparation, then ceasefire, and eventually alliance.

The leader was a genius. He developed a tissue printer to fabricate organs, improved prosthesis to a level where they function better than the organic original. Their new trade was in advanced bionic prosthesis, and they'd treat anyone that requested aid.

A decade passes as they continued to grow in spite of the mechanoid threat. Eventually they were able to build a vessel complex enough to sail through space and return to a Glitterworld, but instead of the three who crash landed so many years ago, it was the twenty-four men and women of Fishyville and their dog, Lunaroni.

11/10. Put 110 hours in on my first colony. Didn't even want to end it, but wanted to do another start with everything I'd learned plus the DLCs. Sanguophages and Mechanitors sound like incredible fun. I really wish I bought this when it came out. I could have been having this level of fun for the last 5 years.

the journey of a rimworld player:
1: introduction

130102615.review:
RimWorld, in its creator's words, is not a game per se, but a story generator.
As far as I'm concerned, it stands at the peak of colony management / base building games, much like its spiritual predecessor Dwarf Fortress.

One playthrough, if you can call it that, sees you manage a colony at first consisting of crashlanded survivors, or a small group of tribals, or a single dude hungry for adventure depending on starting settings, to wherever you want to take that start. Everything from a single hermit living in a cabin in the woods, living off the land surrounding him to bustling fortresses or mega-cities that fill the entire map with buildings and facilities is possible. No two games of RimWorld are the same, because you can set up in a large variety of biomes each time, from lush jungles to ice sheets at the polar caps, but even if you settle in temperate forests each and every time, what makes the game stand out are the pawns themselves. Each one is unique, from their name to their interests and their interactions between each other. Like I said in the beginning, RimWorld calls itself a story generator and here it is where you really see that premise in action. You can get emotionally attached to your pawns to a degree that makes it feel pretty great to see them thrive, and devastating to lose them to disasters, raids, the environment or hunger if you're really unlucky. 

Past the basegame there are three DLCs at time of writing and every single one of them was created with great care by Ludeon. Each one of these deserve their own review, but they speak volumes of the love Ludeon have for their baby. 

Lastly, the mod support for this game is off the charts. Whatever your hearts desire, if it's not in the game already, there's probably a mod for it.

In conclusion, 11/10, well worth the 1200 hours I put into it.

127474218.review:
This is my first review, so It's going to be short and sweet (hopefully).

So RimWorld. What a game, eh? I absolutely love this game. I'm not very good at it, but I love it. I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to try a "Colony Management" game.

What is RimWorld?

Well, RimWorld is a top-down, simplistic-looking colony survival game. While the game seems simple, it is very in depth. You must manage a colony of about three crash-landed survivors (if you choose that scenario) on a hostile planet. There's no feeling more satisfying than watching your colony grow. There will be heartache and anger, but It's all worth it in the end.

From what I've played, I really can't think of any cons or bad things about this game. And, if you're like me, and can't get enough of this game, then you're in luck. RimWorld had three DLCs, all of which are filled to the brim with content, and a massive modding community.

I cannot recommend this game enough.

It's a very fun game to put all your focus into. However, you can also just pull up the game and put a show on or something to watch while you're playing it. It's a beautiful game and the mods make the experience even better. Great job developers!

With that said though it is by no means a perfect product but the community, the mods, and the constant evolving of the game makes it so good. The endless possibilities, the random crazy stuff that happens, the harsh reality and the cruelness of life in the Rimworld, and that no run is the same in any way keeps you dragged into this world for hours and hours at end... So if you like these kind of games and got a life to waste then I recommend highly!
PS: Fun thing to do is naming your pawns with your friends names and then tell your friends about what they've been up to in the world of Rimworld, can make for some hilarious stories.

I bought this game when it was in beta, around December 2017. 

Very addicting, AMAZING soundtrack. In the first 2 months, I logged over 300 hours in this game lol. Over 1000 hours later, and I'm still not bored of it. Not to mention the devs keep coming out with more DLC to spice things up, and there are TONS of great mods for it if vanilla isn't your thing.

Admittedly there is a bit of learning curve there if you are not used to having to micromanage EVERYTHING, and learning each of the various parts to the game can feel overwhelming at first. But, there is a good inbuilt tutorial that can help you get started, and once you really sink your teeth in (and probably after you've wiped out a few colonies) - you get the hang of it. 

If you like survival colony builders with a lot of challenge and depth, then this is the game for you. Although the colonists look like pawns, each one has a little backstory alongside a set of physical and psychological traits and skills that will effect how they interact with other colonists and the success of the colony overall as you try to survive. The permadeath mode makes the drama all the more real - because the death of a colonist can be so truly impactful on the story each game run tells.  Essentially what the game lacks in graphics, it more than makes up for in story-telling and gameplay.

The game is so comfy and cosy, but equally stressful and you need to have good tactics and strategy for taking on the most deadly enemies. Micro-managing is a must.  At some stage when I figure out how to write better I will update this review to show how awesome this game truly is and how much I really love it. 

Highly, highly recommend.

126106884.review:
Rimworld is a Colony Management game developed by Ludeon Studios. In it, you take control over several coloniest or pawns and strive to develop a colony capable of not just surviving life on a bitter rim world, but thriving with the eventual goal of creating a ship to escape back to the stars. Rather than having direct control over the colonists you give general orders to your colony as a whole, tasking them to build buildings, harvest crops or hunt animals. These tasks are completed in an order determined by a combination of pawn priority, skill level, and a small degree of luck depending on the situation.
Rimworld is more than just a colony manager, it is a story generator as any avid player can attest to. Each individual game of Rimworld is different from the last, with random events and player choices making unique memories, whether it be in the form of an escaped farm animal eating a colonies supply of recreational drugs, giant insects eating a group of raiders, or a pawn killing half your colony because he had to eat without a table.
Ludeon Studios has poured a lot of work into Rimworld, but more than creating an incredible game they have also fostered an incredible community, with an active playerbase and an incredibly extensive modding community as well. If there is something you could think to add to Rimworld, there probably already is a mod for it.
With both an incredible base game and extensive mods available, Rimworld is an easy recommendation for any person looking to lose a few thousand hours in a colony management sim.

Before you know it, you are weaponizing your tamed bears to protect your colonists from some drugged up raiders who are coming to raze your settlement and kidnap your best doctor. (Go fuck yourself, Kevin) Amazing.

124852319.review:
Rimworld is a colony sim; aka, manage a ever expanding group of colonists to survive and thrive on an unknown world that you have crashed onto. Turn the natural resources into your home and your food. Grow raw produce and hunt animals to create food. Chop down wood and mine for resources to build and craft. Research new technologies to improve the way your colonist live and defend themselves. Build defenses and craft weapons to defend yourself against the unwashed hordes of pirates, enemy tribes and robots. And before you know it, you have yourself a well-oiled machine that can self-sustain itself.

This game, is one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had in a game in a very long time. There is just so much you can do and no two playthroughs will ever be the same. The storytellers help create a fresh experience each and every time you play. Randomized events, pawns and factions give upon thee challenges and goals to strive towards. Relatively simple yet complex building systems can please those who like building; while similarly complex combat systems will please the Strategy and RTS gamers. 

Difficulty settings can range from Peaceful with no threats, to semi-challenging but fair, all the way to a merciless brutal setting that challenges everything you know. If those aren't specific enough, you can adjust specific settings to create an ideal play style for you. Don't be afraid to take it easier if you find that it gets overwhelming; or if you're not feeling challenged enough, ramp those sliders up for a tougher challenge. There is no "right" way to play this game, and I find that beautiful.

The game has a bit of a learning curve at the start but once you overcome it, however the game has a exponential fun curve as well. I recommend, at least for your first colony to not be afraid of save-scumming. Events can and mostly likely will happen that can completely wipe your colony of the face of the map and sometimes your colonists might just walk straight into a firefight cause they do not have common sense LOL.

Each of the DLCs are fantastically crafted, which expand heavily upon the base game and create brand new ways to expand and personalize your playthrough.

Royalty gives you opportunities to build a standing with your local empire, allowing a colonist to rise through the ranks of the monarchy. You can gain benefits of a new trading partner, calling for labor or defensive favors, and unlocking a new way to complete the game by reaching the highest rank and getting a free ride of the planet.

Ideology completely shakes up the game by allowing you to create a religion and culture that's catered to the way you like to play. Like staying underground in mountains? You can make your colonists love the dark, being inside and be spectacular at mining; but also hate the outdoors and sunlight. Want your colonists to be a horde of violent cannibals? You can set your colonists to love human meat and love raiding; but can get restless if they don't go out and pillage. I have yet to play this DLC, but the implications and the possibilities is definitely worth a recommendation from me. 

Finally, the most recent release of Biotech adds even more to the ever expansive list of things to do. Children, genetic modification and the ability to control robots (mechanoids). I haven't gotten too in depth into this expansion yet, however a brand new level of management with children, being able to tailor suit your colonists with perks and downsides, as well as create your own robotic defense and labor force is a great new step into the expanse that is RImworld.

And finally. once you've become acquainted with Rimworld's oddities and systems; I would 100% recommend looking into modding your experience. The mod community is massive and regularly updates. Definitely check out some of the QoL mods like "Common Sense," or "Pick Up n' Haul," which can make a big difference for improving efficiency and preventing some stupid behaviors. I recommend checking out Noobert on YouTube, he has plenty of videos that give some great recommendations for mods and has some great content. Mods can also greatly expand the content in the game, check out Vanilla Expanded Pack, which can easily be considered an unofficial Expansion pack. Heck, if you're a fan of making your own modifications; the game's modding scene is fairly easy to get into.

Overall, Rimworld is very massive in scope and has infinite replayability. You could have colonies that last a year the go down in a barrage of flames and disease, or you could have a colony that stands the tests of time and struggle and create a thriving city. I absolutely love this game and I 100% recommend it

124316858.review:
Long story short. This game is beyond good.

Think of it as sci-fi Dwarf Fortress of sorts. But with actual interface and graphics that do not try to burn your eyes out. 

Sure, it may lack the absolutely insane complexity of Dwarf Fortress, but it is not a bad thing at all - in exchange, you get the game that is still very complex, very brutal at times, and still far more approachable.
It is still a hard and unforgiving game, if you let it to be this way - 3 basic storytellers are still pretty customizable, and give you some solid variety - and you can downloaded modded ones if you wish.

The name of the game is customisation - you have tons of options on how to play, what to do, what not to do and expansions adds massive layers of new options on top.
And you have mods, tons of them, for pretty much anything you want - quality of life improvements, general content, overhauls big and small.
You want your colony to be a bunch of nature-worshipping technophobes? You can do that.
You want them to be imperialistic slavers? Sure thing, why not?
A bunch of bloodthirsty cannibals? Yep, you can be.
A group taken directly from Cyberpunk, with augmentations so vast you can hardly call them human any more? It is there.
A mix of the above? Absolutely.
You can make your colony into normal survivors, or a complete den of insanity run by colonists who make biggest war criminals in history look like puppies. It is your choice.

It is a sandbox in pretty much purest form.

124260277.review:
I'm not a game reviewer, but I have played this game extensively

Rimworld is the video game incarnation of the phrase "But I can do it better next time".

Premise is simple: you choose your first few pawns, choose a tile on the globe, and protect your pawns with your life. Those poor little guys and gals can be killed by just about anything and in rare occasions, each other. Your job is to create a base for them and assign specific tasks for them to do whether it be mining, farming, cleaning, or collecting resources among others. During this, the game will try to throw different events at your and depending on the AI you chose at the start, these events will be more lenient or more deadly. 

From playing through, you will learn how to do things better and more efficiently, and thus you will start again with your new knowledge and hope that the RNG doesn't throw things to the wall in a tantrum. And if it does, you start again with even more experience and do better and better, but that will never end. It's the perfect gameplay loop of "But I can do it better next time", and that's what makes it so fun to play over and over. 

Other than this, the modding community is fantastic and has created mods for thousands of different things you can drop into the game to do even better, or make things more difficult.

124053027.review:
So I had 3 survivors. Kevin, who liked to hunt, Mikhail, who was a little all-around, and had a slight bit of first aid knowledge, and No, who was our doctor. A wild man locked himself in our refrigerator, ate all the food there, and starved to death without our notice. The colonists were able to restock the food paste machine but kept getting upset that there was a corpse hanging around. I hadn't managed to get them to build a crematory yet. To get the corpse out of their sight Kevin thought he'd butcher him and turn him into kibble. That way the corpse would be gone and the livestock would have something to eat for a while. It upset him more than he thought to prepare it but he recovered and moved on. Then we collected a prisoner named Michael who was injured. We were in the midst of nursing him back to health when the doctor, No, decided to starve himself half to death then eat the human kibble. The food paste machine was functional and fully stocked and he was supposed to eat it but no. No got upset that he'd been hungry. He got further upset that he ate kibble. Then he got Really upset when he realized the kibble was human. He abandoned the injured prisoner and went on a sad wander. While this was going on, a panther or jaguar or something got too close to our camp and started causing trouble. Both Kevin and Mikhail decided to fight it off. Mikhail got scratched up pretty badly and started to bleed profusely. Kevin took him to the infirmary and tried to tend to him as well as he could without any medical skill. He managed to stop the bleeding then ran over to try to save the prisoner that No had abandoned but the prisoner died. Kevin was very stressed trying to keep people alive. Mikhail developed an infection in his leg. Kevin snapped and had a psychotic break. He went to find No and tried to beat him to death. Luckily he got distracted by the livestock once No fell to the ground and he eventually got taken out by a goose. No was able to pull himself together a little and went to tend to Mikhail's infection. It was running rampant and to prevent him from going septic he was going to have to amputate. This would be No's first surgery. It failed catastrophically and left Mikhail with a ripped-off leg and profuse bleeding. No ran off to go get some more medicine and Mikhail unfortunately perished. All that's left is a failed doctor who abandons people when they need him most and doesn't have the sense to eat human food instead of kibble. 

That should be the end. The game felt sorry for me and tried to throw a crashed pod with a human in it my way to bolster my ranks but he landed in the river and died. 
Oh, I'm playing on the easiest build-and-relax mode, by the way.

123958856.review:
As I clear 1,000 hours in Rimworld, and begin to appreciate how hours accumulate into days, I notice that my thoughts about this game have started to crystalize around a few main points.

The first thing to observe is that Rimworld has become the game against which I measure every other game I play. This reality began to grow in mind as an unpleasant one; it is the feeling one has when they wish they could forget their favorite book, only to have the intense pleasure of reading it again for the 'first' time. This second first reading is not given to us. We must console ourselves instead with browsing further afield, while secretly knowing that what we really expect is to be disappointed. Typically we are.

The second point; quite without knowing it, Rimworld has changed the way I approach gaming. No longer for me the endless, mindless grind; let me build a system, and then step back and enjoy its operation. How many of these thousand hours did I spend simply watching the game play, when there was nothing left to build? In most survival games the micromanagement is inescapable. I find them almost unplayable now. Rimworld is psychologically satisfying in this respect--beginning with scarcity, and lacking everything, you can over time begin to achieve a measure of security and stability. 

Third point; Mods can make a game, or break one. I probably spent the first four or five hundred hours playing strictly vanilla. My modlist is always changing, but whatever mods I run, I very rarely run without them now. When I do rarely play a vanilla run, I notice two things; it lacks the depth I've grown accustomed to, and it's more difficult than I remember. Have mods turned me into a soft target?

Lastly, everything has its time and everything dies. I might be losing interest in games, or maybe I just need a long break. But if there's ever a time to rethink one's priorities, the thousand-hour mark is as good as any. And yet I feel I can say with confidence that, sooner or later, I'll see you on the Rim.

Rimworld can almost be whatever you want it to be. It can be brutal and challenging, it can be interesting and unexpected. They keep adding things to allow for more customization and more depth.

So I'm trying the new expansion, and I'm working with a Sanguiphage. It's pretty interesting, and I feel like it's a solid Rimworld perspective on vampires. At any rate, three of the pigmen show up looking for trouble. I presently have two soldiers and a nonviolent pawn. Right off the bat, a lynx targets one of the pigmen (do animals really like to attack them? Unclear, but this seems like good evidence that they do). That pigman and its comrades kill the lynx, but not without taking some good damage.

The other two get closer, and I engage them. My swordsman promptly kills the second pigman, but is downed. My sanguiphage engages. There's a fire fight, but ultimately my sanguiphage is down as well. I manage to save my swordpawn, but the sanguiphage is captured, and the pigman is running hard for the edge of the map. They pass a wolf, which decides that pigman is tasty. It was amazing.

132730234.review:
TL:DR: Colony sim story generator with near infinite replayability, an amazing modding community and barely any limits on playstyle. And it will always without fault, make hilarious and tragic stories for you to tell your friends and family.

So, you want to buy rimworld? Let me tell you about the chaos your about to bring apon yourself. 

Rimworld is first and foremost a story generator game. Your trapped on a rimworld in the far reaches of space with nothing but your colonists, meager supplies and the bounty of the land before you. And its your job to turn this crashlanding into a thriving colony. Surviving everything the planet throws at you. From people having mental breakdowns to being attacked by a horde of aggressive manhunting squirrels, 200 strong in numbers, and many many more weird events. And you can go about surviving these any way you want. Theres no limits or laws on the Rim. Which allows you to do some really fecked up things to get by. From cannibalism, drug abuse, organ harvesting, slavery and many many other things. 

No two runs will EVER be the same in this game. Theres near infinite replayability. Especially when you name colonists after your friends and family. Yes you will get attached to them, and it will suck when they die. But you can tell that one friend how their rimworld equivalent tried to tame a wild rockhopper penguin by spanking it to assert dominance. Or how they carved two legendary statues that the entire planet knows about, which one depicts another friend becoming incapacitated by drug overdose, and the other friend being shot by an evil overbearing clown (These actually happened and I have photos). And dont even get me started on the mods. 

This game is like Garrys mod. Its good by itself, but absolutely amazing with mods. The modding community in this game is absolutely bonkers. There are mods out there for everyone. From new storytellers (They are the AI overlords that plan out the events to keep your game interesting. All hail Randy Random!), to new weapons, enemies, creatures, biomes, vehicles, buildings, etc. You name it. Its likely there. Theres even mods that allow custom built spaceships you can live on and travel in. Which was never intended in the base game.

The game also has DLC if you feel like picking those up. Which I highly, highly recommend. As they add so much more flavour to the game. The prices may be quite steep for DLC, but they also act as framework for modders, allowing them to add content onto said DLC for an even greater, more customisable experience. Plus you get to support a pretty damn cool developer in the process. 

Theres so much more I could talk about with this game, but I think Ill finish it off here with one last, rather important thing. Due to how the game was made, it *can* run quite slow sometimes if you overload it with mods, even with an extremely powerful PC. As this games ancient engine is unfortunately only able to run on one CPU core without completely breaking the game. And the developers cant really do anything about it, as an engine rewrite to allow it to work on all cores would completely break every single mod on the workshop. However, there ARE mods out there that massively improve performance. My favourite in particular being RocketMan. So do with that what you will. 

But yeah. Thats a small taste of the rimworld experience. Its by far one of my most loved games of all time. The fact the game will without fault make absolutely hilarious, and tragic stories that you can tell your friends and family about is something that keeps the game so entertaining. Theres very few games out there that can match it in that regard. The most notable of those being Dwarf Fortress, which the game was heavily inspired by. Just to give you an idea of the depth it can go. So I definitely recommend you pick it up and give it a try. Or if your unsure, watch some youtube videos on it. Its a game you likely wont regret purchasing

140324252.review:
In my opinion the best game on steam so I'll finally bother making a review on it.

Played since the official 1.0 release and it's only gotten better with updates/expansions.
The game is an amazing colony simulator that looks a hell of a lot simpler than it is. 
I'll explain one of my recent playthroughs:

Started as a solo machine controlling man, the name being Walter White.
I slowly build my army of robots, ever expanding my drug empire of cocaine. I buy a few slaves that I insert mind controlling bionics so they can become my drug runners. I made it so robots couldn't attack me but buffed human attacks and by the late game I'd use massive amounts of poisonous gas to demolish anyone who dares stand in the way of the one who knocks. Eventually I decide I've reached the money I want and just spawn tons of waves of attacks to see if I can hold.

About the expansions. They're a bit pricy sure but this is a game where you won't really notice not having the expansions. It's no Paradox game. I recommend them once you've been playing the game a bit. 

Lastly a reason I love these developers. When the recent DLC Biotech came out it added things like Vampires. The DLC before it, Ideology, added "ideoligions". The devs had the philosophy of wanting each DLC to stand on its own so there was no real integration between the new races of Biotech & the Ideologies of Ideology. If people wanted it a mod would be made. People however did massively request this integration of the DLC's so it was added by the developers. I like that they have the philosophy of not making DLC need other DLC, but I love it even more that they listened to players (and this is just one example).

Final verdict: 0/10: main developer is canadian, also buy his book (Designing Games: A Guide to Engineering Experiences)

I've played a lot of Rimworld (ahem, waaay more than Steam shows). I love this game. Colony sims have a special place in my heart, even more so the ones that can be really rough and rather ruthless when it comes to knocking you down a couple pegs. Rimworld is a good game. It's hard, and some of the mechanics can become really frustrating, but it also has a strong modding community, which I think is essential for replayability-- even in a game like Rimworld where no two colonies will be exactly the same! If you like building bases, fighting off waves of enemies, managing a group of rather grouchy and occasionally insane colonists, then Rimworld might be the game for you. There's a lot here for fans of many gameplay styles to enjoy. And when you finish playing around with the base game + dlc, there's always plenty of mods to spice things up.

9/10 Because it still has some work to do within the base game itself, but is essentially there. +1 if you add mods for a full 10/10.

Love this game its so unique, so before i bought  this i held off a long time as the graphics are not amazing but after playing the game it more than makes up for that in the stories it generates around your colonists.

You have to realise the fun even in losing but yes an awesome colony sim. I have over 200 hours and I havent got near to finishing (I never save scum in games so dead is dead). Its basically about a group of your colonists dropped on a hostile planet who have to survive, building protection and a home, trading hunting and growing food. 

My latest game which has just prompted me to write this i was doing so well, had a colony of 7 and 3 prisoners. An enemy group dropped in on my colony in pods and immediatly attacked with my best fighters going down early on in the fight. 2 died, and the other 4 were carried off with only 1 girl surviving who doesnt fight, she hid in the food cellar till they went. Her only choice when they had gone was to go get one of the prisoners and get him to help her. 

Its going to be an interesting game from now on, can the two of them survive, will i be able to rescue the kidnapped friends (yes that happens sometimes thats how awesome the game is. Will this colony die now i have only 2 people left. 

These are the things which make this game so great, i would say if you are interested watch some you tube vids and get an idea, if you like the idea of story driven game where its not about winning its about the journey then this game is great for you. If you cant cope with loss and colonies being damaged late game you can always save scum to miss that but i would recommend playing and feeling the struggle and comeback its part of what makes the game great. 

So all in all would really recommend, once you figure more of the game out the more awesome it becomes.

Ps i set up a trap in the cave storage to get the bug infestations we keep getting and one of my dumb guys stood on it, so thats an example of how real this game can be. 

Recommended go get it and make some amazing stories.

138381453.review:
Introduction:
RimWorld, developed by Ludeon Studios, is a captivating and immersive sci-fi colony management game that will test your strategic thinking, resource management, and moral decision-making. Set in a procedurally generated world, this unique game offers a relentless experience where you guide a group of survivors through various challenges, unpredictable events, and the ultimate goal of building a thriving colony.

Gameplay:
The gameplay of RimWorld is where it truly shines. You start with three stranded survivors, each with their own distinct personality traits, strengths, and weaknesses. As their leader, you must provide shelter, food, and security while managing their emotional needs. From constructing buildings and growing crops to hunting wildlife and researching advanced technologies, every decision affects your colony's survival.

One of the game's core elements is the complex AI storyteller, which generates events and crises based on the overall situation. Whether it's a raid from hostile factions, a disease outbreak, or even a catastrophic weather event, RimWorld keeps you on your toes at all times. This dynamic storytelling feature ensures that each playthrough feels unique and challenging, making every decision and resource allocation critical.

The depth of RimWorld's mechanics is remarkable. You'll have to assign tasks to colonists based on their abilities, deal with relationships and conflicts, and perform surgeries and medical treatments. The game's detailed combat system adds another layer of complexity, allowing you to set up traps, engage in tactical battles, and defend your colony from outside threats.

Graphics and Sound:
While RimWorld's graphics are not visually stunning, they adopt a charming pixel art style that effectively conveys the game's atmosphere. The user interface is clean, intuitive, and allows easy access to all the vital information you need to manage your colony. The sound design is minimalistic yet effective, with ambient soundscapes and occasional music that create a tense and immersive atmosphere.

Modding Community:
RimWorld benefits immensely from its passionate modding community. The Steam Workshop integration allows players to browse and install a vast array of mods that can significantly enhance gameplay, add new content, and tailor the experience to their liking. From quality-of-life improvements to complete overhauls, the modding scene ensures that RimWorld never feels stale, extending its replay value indefinitely.

Replay Value:
Speaking of replay value, RimWorld excels in providing endless possibilities. With multiple biomes, different AI storytellers, and various starting scenarios, each playthrough presents new challenges and opportunities. The game's permadeath feature adds tension, making every decision and loss impactful. Whether you're aiming to build a utopian society, embrace cannibalism for survival, or experiment with futuristic technology, RimWorld accommodates a wide range of playstyles and encourages creativity.

Conclusion:
RimWorld is a masterpiece of simulation and strategy, offering an addictive and rewarding experience for those willing to immerse themselves in its complex world. With its challenging gameplay, emergent storytelling, and the endless possibilities offered by its modding community, RimWorld stands as a testament to the power of indie game development. Despite its simplistic visuals, this game will keep you engrossed for hours on end, always yearning for one more day in your ever-growing colony. If you have a passion for strategy, management, and moral dilemmas, RimWorld is an absolute must-play.

Do you like colony sims? 

If yes, the buy this what are you doing? If no, then maybe ask yourself if you'd like to try one anyway?

The advertising for this game barley scratches the depth of what you can do. It's insanely detailed, but easy to understand. I didn't notice too many game systems that I wanted to avoid.

The amount of satisfaction I got by completing 'the main quest' was great. I'll never forget it.

Still reading this? Then pick up the game, it's tons of fun.

For adults, pausing the game is a pretty important part of the game, so it's SUPER EASY to put the game on hold when life pops up (great for working from home).

For beginners, just jump in and don't take ANYTHING too seriously when starting out. Don't spend hours rerolling pawns, or starting new colonies looking for 'the perfect map'. This game does a great job of handing you random problems to deal with, which might be hard while learning the game systems, but ends up being what makes colony yours!

I hope you enjoy this game as much as I have already.

Who can resist the allure of a game that will punch you in the balls and then smile about it.

Better grow some crops before winter gets here. Uh oh, are those raiders? Better hope you have someone that can point a gun in the right direction.

I recommend running a commitment mode playthrough, where you cant reload saves and losses are final, I find that does actually make the game more fun and adds some real interesting situations. That being said, total colony wipes are totally a possibility.

In order to sustain my colony of vampires, I needed a stable source of blood. The only way to get blood is from other humanoids, but the non-vampire colonists get very upset if the vampires take their blood. So I started capturing raiders, and imprisoning them to harvest their blood. Eventually my colony got so large, with so many vampires, that I had to build a very significant amount of infrastructure just to accommodate the prisoners in the blood-farm. Because there were so many prisoners, all of whom were very unhappy with their treatment, there were frequent riots and escape attempts. The most efficient solution to combat this problem that I could think of was to remove the prisoner's hands and legs, so even if they decided to rebel, they would be unable to move or fight. I never had another prisoner cause problems after that.
10/10 game.
