124380235.review:
(Was gifted this game.)

Base Rimworld is a pretty solid experience. The premise of the game is that it's a "story generator" with different storytellers. Each has their own style (read: difficulty curve). Additionally, their difficulty settings can be set from a number of different options. You can pick anywhere from "I'm playing just to take it easy", "Crush my soul into splinters", and the whole gamut between. You can customize most anything you'd like about resources, difficulty, colonists, world seed, and more at the very start. After that, pick your starting tile and then best of luck surviving.

That's a looooong preface namely to describe what makes Rimworld so fun. Such varied, granular customization at the beginning lets you pick so many options for how you want to play. Want an easy, relaxed game of building your isometric dream home? Sure! Want a run with combat, death, struggle, and disease? Absolutely! Try out the nomadic lifestyle humanity started out as? Go ahead! Even if the amount of control you have over the world is lessened after you pick the settings, you can still adjust difficulty and the storyteller (difficulty curve) anytime you like.

After starting, you won't have as much control. You'll have to learn the mechanics and find new recruits (if you want), warts and all. Farming, hunting, ranching, researching, trading, etc. From keeping people alive on rice to cooking food fit for a king. I'll not go into all kinds of mechanics here, but needless to say even the same seed, same start, and same colonists can have radically different, interesting runs on the same settings based on player choices.

Overall, I've got mostly positive experiences with this game. It's a fun time playing around with the different options, starting different colonies, and more. The game has a nice enough soundtrack you may listen to if desired, or simply put your own music on in the background. Sound effects are pleasing and distinct enough to know what's what. Notifications are (mostly) timely and helpful. The graphics aren't state-of-the-art, but have their own charm if you're a fan of the 2D, simple style the game has. Speed options keep things moving for you so you're not waiting forever for that one chef to make your meal. Even giving the player the reigns, quests, raids, and more pop up to keep things interesting and break up the monotony and provide a modicum of structure. You decide how long the game should go on. Build up, abandon the colony, and make your way to the hidden ship? Build your own ship? Don't stop and live forever on the rim? Your choice.

Negatively speaking, while the game's soundtrack is wonderful, listening to the same few songs on end is exhausting. Some colonist traits are simply too severe to risk, which does limit options. Gourmand and Pyromaniac colonists are too destructive in a game where resources are not only your currency, but lifeblood. You'll need to arrest them often, beat them down, both, or sometimes end up killing them if you want to avoid massive resource drain whenever they have their destructive moods. Melee is significantly inferior to ranged. By even the mid-game, you'll be wanting people with guns for hunting and fighting. I'm at less risk of losing a limb in a scuffle or firefight with a decent enough revolver than I am with a blade that could match Excalibur, even when armored. Resource sprawl can get out of control. Gaining wealth means more people want to steal from you and notice you, but as you accrue resources, it gets harder to take you down. You'll either fizzle out or just snowball into an unstoppable juggernaut without micromanaging your wealth to avoid either. Also, why no artificial noses? I can build bionic arms, legs, hearts, and more...but I can't make a fake nose if someone's is broken?

This is an ideal game for those looking for a colony sim that's a nice balance between mechanical, roleplay (whether or not you yourself opt into it), and random. It's never unapproachable, offers endless hours of random fun, and options. If you need something more mathematical, thematic, or structured, games like Oxygen Not Included, Frostpunk, or Surviving Mars may be what you want instead.

TL;DR: Iz gud gayme. Hav fun.

131084868.review:
This game will suck your soul right out of your body and give it to me. I accidentally sat up 5 hours past my bedtime because I couldn't let it go.

RimWorld is hands down one of the most enjoyable and addictive games I've ever played. It's all about building and managing a colony, and let me tell you, it's so much fun! The mechanics are deep and there's always something to do, whether it's building new structures, training your colonists, or dealing with random events that pop up. And the best part is, every time you play, the game generates a new world so it's never the same experience twice.

One of the things I love most about RimWorld is the AI storyteller system. It basically controls the pace and direction of the game, and it keeps things interesting by throwing curveballs at you when you least expect it. One moment, you'll be cruising along, and the next, you'll have a massive raid on your hands. It's intense, but it's also really satisfying when you're able to come out on top.

The modding community for RimWorld is also amazing. There are so many mods out there that add new content and gameplay options, it's insane. I've added a ton of mods to my game and it's just made the experience even better. From new buildings and items to new types of colonists and events, there's always something new to discover.

124219841.review:
This game does a lot right, and so do the developers. The devs are really responsive. Every other review that tells a story of a crazy emergent gameplay scenario, intense raid or just praising the gameplay are all right, so I wont add any of that here. Plus I used to have a positive review with my own such story, that I removed after the 2nd DLC came out. 

But its time for me to make a point. 

This review has to do with the DLC policy they have been trending with. Royalty was $20 (USD), Ideology was $20, and now Biotech is $25. The DLCs are roughly twice price of the base game. This is beginning to border on greed. 

In addition, the DLCs seem to take a lot from existing mods, then they rewrap it some and sell it back to us. Not to mention that these DLCs come with major version updates that invariably break many mods, and some of those mods never come back, sort of reducing the total customize-ability of the game and reducing the content threshold for about the same amount that the DLC adds. I understand that there are mods for basically anything in rimworld and that the devs adding new features would likely step on someone's toes, but adding a DLC that just does something that mods already do is... questionable. Add in the rising price and the fact that the base game is now about 0.52 the value of the DLCs themselves, and I've had enough. 

To be fair the concent alone wasn't really an issue with the first two DLCs, which seemed to try to do something that mods werent QUITE doing yet. but this is also the THIRD one, is 20% more than the other ones, and just takes mods or mod ideas already out there and makes them 'official' by reselling them to us, 

For the first time, I am not buying this DLC. The rest were basically auto buys. But no longer. 

I would like to see if the devs address the concerns of the community in a meaningful way before getting this and I hope those who agree follow suit for now. They've always been adaptable and responsive, I'll wait to see it in action again. Maybe we are wrong, maybe they are, all I know is that we all make mistakes and fixing them should be priority once identified.
124219841.developer_response:
Hi there eden,

Regarding price, here's what I wrote about this in the last Biotech preview:

"Biotech will be priced slightly differently from our previous expansions, at $24.99 USD. (Other territories have different prices on Steam.) We hired a lot of people and took a lot of time (15 months) to make Biotech because that’s what it took to properly explore the ideas that we set out to explore. The feature set got big enough that we seriously discussed splitting this into two expansions, but decided to keep it as one.

Some companies have a “cost first” model where they decide up front to make an expansion in a fixed time/price (e.g. 6 months/$20) and force the creative process to live in those constraints. We take ideas and build them until they feel well-rounded and complete. We believe that different ideas naturally take different amounts of resources to explore, so it must be okay for different expansions to have different prices, for the same reason different games have different prices. Forcing every expansion to have the same price would mean trying to squeeze or stretch every idea into the same amount of production resources, which is not a path to creative flourishing. That’s why our expansions aren’t all priced the same - because they’re different in scope, because that’s what the ideas wanted."

Regarding mods - There are over 17,000 mods for RimWorld on the Steam workshop. Many of them are based on ideas from my fiction that I wrote way back in 2012, before RimWorld was even announced, and which I published as the "RimWorld fiction primer". Many others are based on ideas that are simply natural and obvious - children, mechanoid control, etc.

We don't go around looking at mods to take anything from them; I don't pay much attention to them at all. Certainly we don't take assets from them, and we implement everything ourselves.

However, please understand that there are only a certain number of natural ways to add to this game. With 17,000 mods, basically all of those have been done, often several times. If we were trying to treat the 17,000 mods as a minefield where we can't touch something that someone else did some version of, it would simply be impossible for us to add anything. Oftentimes a similar mod comes out after we start development of the expansion, too.

I'm afraid these kinds of criticisms are a major reason many devs work to stifle modding, or just don't support it. We've done everything we could to support modding the game, and the result is that there are 17,000 mods - and then when we try to add anything ourselves we get attacked for any overlaps that may exist.

It's a punishment for helping the mod community flourish, and for not abandoning the game. I don't feel these are really behaviors you want to punish in game developers. This negative review would never exist if we blocked mods like so many do, or abandoned the game like so many others. Please consider the position we're in, whether we really did something wrong, and what you're really pushing devs to do - either abandon games or stifle mods.

Please also consider that this is a review for RimWorld, which is not a worse game today than it was a week ago. In fact, it's better, since the 1.4 update improves a pile of stuff and adds free content.

It's perfectly fine to not buy an expansion - not every product is for every player. But does the fact that we're trying to make new stuff (that people like - Biotech has 96% rating) make RimWorld a bad game, or make us bad devs? I hope you'll reconsider this review. Because I don't want to block mods and I don't want to abandon the game.

Thanks for writing in any case.

125679985.review: So lets put this in to perspective..  I originally got Rimworld for free during the 2020/21 lockdown.. I was broke, board and looking for something to fill in those extra hours at home.  I thought I'd play a few hours here and there.. next thing I know the lockdown was lifted,  fights opened and work was back on the table.  I probably clocked up around 1000 hours.. the diversity and replayability was endless.. from the casual story lines to the hectic God Randy making your life hell.. from watching your pawns construct your colony to activating dev mode and building crazy colonies, and even after so much play time your still discovering new aspects.   The base game is amazing, and the expansions just brought those little things you didn't know you needed, not to mention the community workshop mods bringing pretty much additional expansions.   This game gives everything you want for its genre,  can it be improved.. sure.. what gamer would not appreciate improvements.. does it need it.. not really.  The main thing is after so much play time, for free, once the option presented itself, I didn't hesitate to purchase the game with all current DLC to support Tynan and his team as Im sure the game will continue to expand and grow, the community is very strong and the future is yet to be written.. Do I recommend this game.. yes 100%..  Thank you Tynan and Team for this seemingly endless gaming fun.

124428411.review:
To start, I am not the type of gamer to play one game consistently. I typically pick up a game, play it for a few hours (if I am lucky) and then drop it. Even my favorite games I typically pick up for a week or so before forgetting about them for months at a time. Not Rimworld. This game has been a staple in my life for a few years now, getting me through college while I was working strange hours and it was just me sitting at my desk alone at 4 in the morning with nothing else to be doing.

The core thing for me about this game is that between the open story generation of the base game and it's DLC and the absolute plethora of mods available, you can have so many different runs that the game never really feels stale.

Modding is a major focus in this game, which is good because the base game is lacking in polish. There's mods that add functionality that is so obvious in its necessity that I forget it's not in the base game because Jesus Christ why would that NOT be in the game?

All that being said. This is my favorite game of all time. It's a fucking masterpiece in its creation and is the only game that I have purchased all of the DLC of day one.

142290424.review:
Saw a YouTuber play this game a few years ago so picked it up on sale.
Dropped in with my 3 colonists and a husky, built a settlement, had a few people join. 
Then my neighbors raided me and one of my colonists got shot in the head. She survived but with permanent brain damage. Fortunately (?) the person who shot her survived, became an involuntary lung donor for another colonists asthmatic lungs. Sent him on his way as a lesson to the hostile Outlanders he came from.

Meanwhile, I had not realized that our colony had 6 people, with only one male and the rest being female.  The man of the colony was apparently loving this arrangement, quite literally as he had not one, not two, but three lovers in the colony.  Oh, did I mention he’s also married?  Well, the dear old wife comes in a raid.  I can only assume this has to do with her husband’s infidelity, though she is also with the faction with our lung donor.  Anyway, they come for vengeance and are driven off, with our poor brain damaged colonist trading favors by putting one through the forehead of our patriarch’s wife. 

He is devastated.  You can tell, because he waited a full day after burying his wife to propose to one of his lover (the now former asthmatic thanks to another organ donation from the raid.  Maybe they’ll learn their lesson this time).

But our story does not end there.  We are now up to our patriarch and 7 women.  Not a single other man.  He gets married, then cheats on his wife and re-marries.  It’s is the most dysfunctional relationship cycle I have seen, and I’m a counselor.

Then our poor brain damaged colonist gets the plague.  Unfortunately she does not survive and there is much sorrow throughout the colony.  Injuries have spread, with our patriarch missing a thumb and having a mangled eye, asthmatic having a painful scar on her leg, and a myriad of others.  So, we did what any right thinking person would do, and began replacing limbs and eyes with bionics.  Also, since harvesting organs as a warning isn’t working, we’ve change tactics to sending them all our excess puppies, because who doesn’t love puppies right?  It seems to be working, and peace is within our grasp.

Now our colony of cyborgs has its eyes set on the stars.

10/10  Would get involved in dysfunction web of relationships and commit crimes against humanity again.  Frankly, I wish I had bought this game years ago.

130069974.review:
On the surface, Rimworld seems to be another generic sci-fi colony survival game with mediocre visuals. After giving this game a bit of slack, I discovered just how deep it truly was.

As far as gameplay is concerned, Rimworld forms itself upon the foundation of the aforementioned colony survival simulator archetype. Though what Rimworld truly is, at its core, is a story-building game. It's a game of hardship, tragedy, despair, and acceptance. It is possible to save-scum in this game, but you're missing out on 4/5ths of the actual experience this game has to offer. Colonists develop complex relationships, crops get botched on harvest by inexperienced farmers, and buildings burn down and debilitate your whole colony for the rest of the year. Rimworld offers not just a story of rugged survival, but of incredible stress and the consequences of hopelessness as well. Watch colonists die, witness disgustingly selfish atrocities take place, and dig your way back up out of the ashes to make something new from what you've lost. There are few scenarios in Rimworld from which your colony cannot truly recover from, and almost nothing you can lose that you cannot recoup or reclaim. And if all else fails? If the final chapter of your long story comes to a close? Then you have something to hold on to as you write a new tale. Embrace the chaos and uncertainty of a hostile world as you not only endure hardships, but eventually come to thrive in spite of them.

[hr][/hr]

I could only describe this game as an [i]everything[/i] simulator. Agriculture, medicine, engineering, economy, supply chains, sociology, warfare/defense, you name it, it's either already in the game or your favorite mod to be for it is already out there. Rimworld is an incredible example of what can come of good concepts in the hands of great developers.

Welcome to Rimworld, travelers. Your destiny awaits.

124116242.review:
What can I say that others have not? This is the survival colony sim by which all others are measured in terms of depth of gameplay even in just vanilla. The interface could always use a quality of life pass, but the real reason for that is because it's difficult to make an interface that is simultaneously uncluttered and accessible to new players as well as full featured when the amount of variables and options the game contains are so numerous. 

Then there's modding support. There are so many add-ons to gameplay and control that it's really hard to get bored.  Need a better interface to search for a good starting location? There's a mod. Want lightsabers? There's a mod. Want to face the horrors of the Old Gods? Cthulhu mods. Want to be Connor MacLeod, the banished immortal? There's a mod, and always wear head armor. Want to change everything to Lord of the Rings? There's mods.  More biomes? More weapons? All there.

About the only thing I really wish was different was the storage mechanics. Having a T-shirt that takes up the same amount of space as a pile of bricks is a bit silly. But if you don't like it, guess what... there's a mod.

This was my favorite game for a long, long, time. I can no longer recommend it. Releasing DLC was one thing- you gotta make money to keep developing, whatever. But lately, Ludeon's been completely brazen about taking possession of mod content created by the community and then re-releasing it as DLC. That's just immoral. Unethical. Somehow you managed to make a model for modded content worse than Bethesda's. I cannot support a company that would take their modders for granted like that, and I'll be damned if I pay money for DLC that renders free mods I previously enjoyed obsolete.

Edit: You're a liar. You've literally taken art assets and mechanics directly from mods I played before you published the DLC. Your EULA specifically states that you reserve the right to redistribute and sell user-created content, specifically including mods, without attribution. I hope your game wallows in obscurity for the crimes you have committed against your community.
125877631.developer_response:
Hi there,
We've never taken any mod content and released it as a DLC. We develop everything ourselves.

Our actual mod mechanics and content are all 100% original; if you look into any of the details you'll see the dramatic differences between any mod and our DLCs in terms of what they actually do.

There are 10,000 mods for RimWorld on the Steam workshop, so of course there will be some general conceptual overlap between anything we do and a mod that has existed. With 10,000 mods, everything has been touched on by modders in some way.

We can't treat 10,000 mods like a minefield where we're not allowed to touch any related idea. Things like xenohumans, vampires, and children are extremely obvious and natural ways to expand the game. (In fact, xenohumans are my concept from my own fiction doc that I wrote in 2013; modders took it from there). There are only so many general conceptual ways to expand the game.

Some conceptual overlap is completely unavoidable and the only way to prevent it would be to block modding. Accusations like this are a major reason that big studios block modding; we don't want to do that. We want to support modding so please help us do that.

I hope you'll consider investigating whether this accusation is actually true and, if it's not, I hope you'll remove this review.

Thanks for enjoying the game in any case; I'm proud to have made a game you've loved for 5,800 hours (wow!)
Cheers
-Ty

PS: the Ludeon FAQ addresses this as well https://ludeon.com/blog/faq/

127178998.review:
I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game.

This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join.

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

124599678.review:
On August 4th, mine and Obama's birthday, a friend of mine gifted me this game. They really wanted me to play it. I heaved a deep sigh and reluctantly tried it out. I'm more of an FPS/RPG person myself and added it the enormous shelf of dusty, gifted games sitting atop my 100+ library, assuming that it would share a similar fate. 

3 months later, and 370 hours in, it's obvious even to my passing acquaintances that I've sold my soul to the devil so I can sate my lusts on endless, looped, infinitely variable gameplay that insists I go all the way to the end, but is so interesting that I can never bring myself to actually ship my colonists to the stars. 

My wife passes by, looking into my dead, bloodshot eyes, nervously smiling and asking if I'm ever going to take another shower again. We haven't had sex since August, and we probably won't anytime soon. The phone calls and texts of concerned friends have gone unanswered. After ignoring his eighth invitation to family dinner, my father has struck my name from the family will and I barely noticed. I didn't really want his library of computer guides from the 1980's anyway, so I don't see what the big deal is.

Bottom line- I've created my own personal hell that I know deep down I will never escape, and part of me doesn't even want to. This is Rimworld. This is my life now. I began my birthday playing this game, and I'll be playing game the day I die. Someone please send help. 

-DimGiant

130152162.review:
got banned in Australia for a bit, that alone should be enough to pique your interest.

Its a solid colony sim with a focus on shaping the story of your colonists. highly modable, but good enough vanilla. Its not actually a warcrime simulator, though warcrimes are on the menu should you wish for it. mods open up new war crime potential, like shelling a town before you invade, or just shelling them because fuck 'em. I personally like to run a colony of bandits that are trying to put their days of bloodshed behind them (which will always result in more bloodshed, as everyone hates you.) someone will eventually die to an attack, revenge arc ensues, etc etc.

games last a long time, which is part of the appeal imo. you get to know these 'pawns' by nickname, you love some that are statistically useless, you hate some that have stellar stats. sometimes you get a useless ding dong that - through sheer luck - keeps surviving when you hurl them at enemies, unshielded, with only a club and some armor, and you kinda come to like them.

so yeah, i recommend it. its kind of a slow burn, but once your in you will find yourself coming back to it from time to time.

145613263.review:
Step 1: accidentally domesticate a breeding population of boomrats because you misread the name as boomalopes
Step 2: realise boomrats are fucking useless, but you can't kill them because they explode when they die so you leave it to focus on other issues, like raiders
Step 3: realise raiders, like predators, will automatically attack your pets if the pet is the closest thing to them that you own. 
Step 4: Boomrats explode when they die, hurting or even killing the melee raiders before they even get close to your pawns. Even better, the ranged raiders keep accidentally shooting their own guys when trying to kill your boomrats
Step 5: breed the ever-loving shit out of boomrats, create a boomrat infestation zone with beds for the boomrats everywhere the raiders might attack from.
Step 6: you have over a hundred living boomrats. you are now immune to raids

Step 7: you realise nothing is getting done around your colony, because keeping animals tame requires constant upkeep.
Step 8: you realise the constant food shortages are because 90% of your food is going into your sacrificial boomrats
Step 9: realise you can't kill them because they explode, and when you factor in the time it takes your colonists to heal from burns they would literally reproduce faster than you kill them, so you have to release all of them into the wild
Step 10: figure out you should have given them all the snip before releasing them so they can't reproduce in the wild
Step 11: over a hundred boomrats is over the wild animal limit for your zone. There are no wild animals other than fucking boomrats. 
Step 12: fuck it, hunt the boomrats into extinction. Your colonists are covered in burns but the menace is gone

Step 13: realise some exotic traders will buy boomrats and you could have just sold them all for roughly 3k silver
Step 14: cry
Step 15: start a Warg breeding program

10/10, I've never felt more like a colonist than I did trying to fix an environment that I ruined myself through my own stupidity. Yes, I really did name the zone 'boomrat infestation zone', that's currently where my Wargs are confined. I have not learned anything.

143613813.review: Rimworld.... what can I say that hasn't already been said. It is the game to end your search for games. Like a relapsing addict, I return to it's familiar hold on my mind every few months. During that time it all but consumes my freedom and will to be a productive member of society. Rimworld has been with me through almost all memorable milestones of my recent life. Through my undergraduate studies, through the first few years of my career, through breakups and new love, through moves across the world and other massive life developments. Whenever I get the "itch" to boot up Rimworld it quickly snowballs into ignoring friends, lovers, and family. I've skipped classes, made up false plans to friends, lied to my employers, and even postponed eating and working out to continue to enjoy life on the Rim. It is the great escape from everything. Endless combinations of mods and scenarios to pursue, it is the ultimate sandbox to act on every desire  from deranged fantasies to morbid curiosities. As I type this, coming off a month long binge, I long for the mental sctratch of a new mod or new DLC to drop so I can return to where I belong. No drug or relationship or experience in this life has compared to what the Rim can offer. Do yourself a favor and stay FAR FAR away from this game unless you never want to live a normal life.

143556497.review:
The game is good, colonists act like people with no direction or ambition unless you control their schedule, which is pretty realistic. For those who are confused about the idea of this game being a "story generator" let me give you an idea. You can try to play this game to win, but unless you do everything "correctly" and in a good timeframe you are relying on luck to not have a bad time. Alternatively, you can run a colony the way you would want to run a colony, and then just take mental note of everything that happens to the colony and the colonists, from start to finish. 

Game is fun and also rage inducing. Infinitely repayable. Heavily Modifiable with a great modding community. Highly Recommend.

132482822.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

145514950.review:
literally the peak of indie gaming imho. a small indie studio from canada, single-handedly made one of the games of the century, defined a genre, all while the whole AAA industry casually sucked and scammed your average Joes... Starfield? no way, i'm buying that crap. Rimworld is offering a better experience in all bloody levels. you want to colonise? you want to fight space punks in an unknown future? you could find a plentiful mecha hives, raiders, pirates and even outlandish tribes etc. and no ones there to stop you from harvesting organs for profit, human trafficking and slavery in this dying, forgotten planet. it's kind of historical to what happened in our world for some millenniums just before everyone's very eyes. and in fact, maybe still is happening while everyone denies and dismiss all the probabilities.

this is going to be a small rant. whatever. the modern world is trying ignore the cruelty of the past, the violence of the humankind to itself and nature, acts of intolerence etc. and cope with it in all possible ways. the modern era has truly some improvements albeit the reminders of the ancient inhumanity are still laying around, underground, maybe next to an ancient city layer, maybe 6 feet under it. just like you know, through time, organic components become fossils. a source for essentially 'modern world'. from petrochemicals to plastic and oil. ironically, we use them to power our vehicles, to make some tyres, to make basic and essential tools to survive and thrive, all while giving out a ton of sizeable goods and money to the holders of these resources etc. and all of the cruelty is suddenly forgotten. the transaction is completed. the cycle repeats itself in a much similar way. not that i'm supporting such things. i'm choosing to not subsidise or turn blind against these violences and inequalities between all groups. to say the least, we already live in a nearly an identical simulation of Rimworld irl. it is because that Rimworld is a 'world' with constant aggresion, survival of the fittest. and i don't think all of us are fit to such a cruel world in any way. unless we don't ignore the very facts just like everyone does. order brings chaos. and vice versa. i think the world we live on is just as doomed as Rimworld.

 nothing is set as a goal in Rimworld, unless if you want to leave this corrupt place altogether, you could go for the stars and never come back again. and that's depressive yet realistic af.

also a technical side note: remember to make your player.log file on /locallow to read-only. or your logs can take up as much space as a couple of Starfield copies in terms of gigabyte or even terabytes. other than that it has an amazing modding community. truly a masterpiece to the core.

142415370.review:
I bought this game on the strength of the stories I read about it, so here’s one of mine:

The Dugout, the fortified stronghold of the Central Independent Tryhards, found itself in the throes of a harrowing raid. Talk about bad timing, though. Their formidable muscle, Shiigen, was still recovering in the hospital from a previous assault. However, Collins, known as "the Boss", the group's capable doctor, fearlessly assumed command on the frontlines.

The raiders aimed to breach the vulnerable northern wall, providing them easy access to the undefended farm. This was a dire situation indeed. The colony's chef, Boone, and skilled architect, Banksy, a couple who had by now seen some shit, swiftly positioned themselves near the barn entrance, located southwest of the wall breach. Meanwhile, Cain, a child who had recently stumbled upon the colony, was given shelter within the barn. As the last line of defense, the group's loyal guard dogs—Abel, Dogmeat, and Stanley (two German shepherds and a pug, respectively)—guarded the entrance by Cain.

With Collins, Boone, and Banksy prepared for the impending onslaught, they braced themselves for the force of approximately ten well-armed raiders. Suddenly, the wall gave way, and Banksy unleashed a torrent of fire from her trusty chain shotgun, immediately dispatching the intruder.

The following trio of raiders swiftly sought cover by the farm fence, engaging in a fierce firefight. Unfortunately, Collins took a hit to the chest, though her trusty flak vest mitigated the worst of the damage. Regrettably, she fell to the ground, incapacitated.

Boone, relying on his trusty revolver, engaged in a fiery exchange with a raider wielding a short bow. However, it was the raider with the axe who seized the opportunity, swiftly cleaving Boone's hand and bringing him down.

As Banksy took aim at the raider who had just felled Boone, her shot narrowly missed. Engaging in a desperate struggle, she eventually struck the raider in the nose with her rifle, rendering them helpless. However, Banksy's guard faltered as an unseen sniper from the breached wall shot off her arm. She joined Boone on the ground, wounded and bleeding out.

Recognizing that they had incurred heavy losses themselves, the raiders decided to retreat, kidnapping any survivors in their path as they made their hasty exit through the breached wall. Just as they thought they had made a clean getaway, a raider carrying Banksy unexpectedly met a brutal end, a swift blow from an axe to the head. The raider beside them tried to flee but found their left leg chopped off by another axe strike, removing them from the fight.

I was already planning how the hell I was going to assemble a rescue mission when out of left fucking field, Shiigen, the heavy sleeper who had been unresponsive in the hospital, had finally emerged. Being high as a kite on smoke leaf and hungry, he had woken up to indulge in some food and a big fatty before catching wind of the ongoing battle and racing to the scene.

Despite two colonists still being carried away by the raiders and Banksy’s life hanging in the balance, Shiigen called out to Cain, urging them to emerge from the safety of the barn with the loyal dogs. Cain rushed to administer crucial first aid to Banksy (a highly recommended mod for situations like these).

Stumbling, his high ass barely registering friend from tree, Shiigen confronted the remaining kidnappers in a valiant effort to halt their escape. Alas, it seemed his actions alone would not suffice. Thankfully, Stanley the pug, hot on Shiigen's trail, delivered a courageous bite that staggered the nearest raider. Tragically, Stanley's heroism proved fatal, as they were struck down while protecting Boone. The fleeing raider attempted to escape, but Abel, the German Shepard, swiftly tore them apart, delivering immediate justice for Stanley.

Finally, the raider carrying Collins, the colony's esteemed doctor and sole hope for healing lost limbs, was on the verge of leaving the map. Not wanting to miss out on the action, Dogmeat, the other German Shepard, lunged forward, bringing down the final raider, while Shiigen approached to deliver the finishing blow with his axe.

When the dust settled and the battle was won, my valiant colonists required urgent triage, having suffered the loss of one hand, two legs, one arm, and even one big toe among the three victims.

Words cannot adequately convey the torrent of emotions that surged through me when that idiot Shiigen stumbled upon the scene. Trust me, just buy the game. It will make you laugh, it will make you cry. You'll embark on retaliatory strikes with overwhelming force against lesser colonies within a single season. Rest in peace Stanley, you magnificent bastard.

I mistook this game for a base builder/base defense game initially, when it was far more of a sims-like colony survival game. Even at that, it seems like it has way too many cumbersome mechanics that aren't explained even through tutorial, and it doesn't have a visible forward direction to follow. Even if you want to get into colony survival genre, I'd say this isn't a good introductory game. Normal game speed is too slow and lacking engagement, and higher game speed makes all the mechanics become knee-deep problems too fast to handle properly by the time they've become apparent. 
Also, the art style just doesn't click with me. It's all weird minimalist shapes reminiscent of indie pixel sprites, so it inherits that bare-bones design philosophy of pixel sprites but without the flavor or charm.

146380365.review:
It's exceedingly rare for a game developer from a small dev studio to have created on of the most influential games of the past decade. While it takes heavy inspiration from Dwarf Fortress, Tynan Sylvester has implemented one of the more complex methods of storytelling in the form of AI storytellers that all control in-game events in unique ways. The complexity of the built-in mechanics warrant their own separate post as I could easily sit here for days discussing aspects such as: temperature, accuracy, skills, colony management, etc. 

For any newcomers just picking up the game, DO NOT buy the DLC until you've completed the tutorial and have spent a few hours learning some of the basics of colony management. Each DLC package - aside from Royalty - completely change several core mechanics of the game while simultaneously making gameplay much harder unless you already have a foundational level of understanding of how the game and the AI storytellers operate. You WILL get slaughtered, several times over, if you decide to go in blind.

Regarding DLC: Biotech and Ideology have taken the core mechanics of the game and introduced concepts which could be entirely separate games in their own right. The additions and changes to core Rimworld mechanics results in a near infinite number of mostly unique scenarios to play through, and each story can often last for several real time days (my longest running colony lasted for 1 full week, or 128 hours of my total playtime). Royalty is the only DLC that you could easily skip and not miss out on much of anything (psycasts were added by mods well before the DLC was created).



Despite recommending others purchase the game I feel obligated to note that the primary reason for Rimworld continuing to dominate the Steam top rate games (currently sitting at #8 as of 9/16/2023) is due to the vast modding community who continually develop and release full size DLC for free. Similar to games like Factorio and Skyrim, modders have provided extensive bug fixes to the game, introduced completely unique game mechanics, and have vastly expanded upon already existing content, each of which add a few hundred hours of playtime in their own right.

1000 hours played now.

The core gameplay is a great canvas on which the extensive mod library creates a really compelling and continually fresh experience. You can do one play through as ultra nice compassionate colonists who help passers-by, who treat their injured enemies and release them or recruit them when healed, you can play as cannibal murderers who only consume the flesh of man and like to decorate their camp with skulls, you can even play as cavemen who slowly but surely build their tech up until they can create laser weapons and edit their DNA to make them super soldiers etc.

When you get tired of one play style there are dozens more to choose from, and with the mod scene as active as it is there are countless new things to discover and try out on a weekly basis.

It's great for role playing, its great for challenges, it's great for sitting back and just making a nice little colony.

That and it tuns on anything, My 1080 burned out a few weeks ago and I head to resort to using my old 970 card and Rimworld ran perfectly fine.

It is also regularly supported with DLC which while a bit pricey, does add a ton of stuff that makes them worth it and it offers mod makers even more stuff to play with.

1000 hours down, and 1000 more to come at least.

Rimworld is a fun game. The options you have available are vast. Want to play as a tribe of hunters? Sure! Want to build a nice western town? Go ahead! Want to build a megasloth ranch? Why not! Want to create the most efficient drug production complex this side of the galaxy? Easy!

The three DLCs expand these options. With Biotech you can create a colony of genetically modified superhumans that have a small legion of roombas cleaning up after them, a vampire lair, or a robotics factory. With Ideology you can make you colonists scar themselves as a ritual, sacrifice livestock (or people) for benefits, make a cannibal cult, or get really sad when they aren't wearing a cowboy hat. With royalty you can make some of your colonists nobility within a technologically advanced empire, gain psychic powers after communing with a weird tree, or use cybernetic implants to make your colonist prettier while giving them subdermal armour plating.

Rimworld is one of my favourite videogames. 10/10

125155606.review:
Steam Deck Settings: 800p @ 60fps on 3watts

Simply put I slept on this one for far too long, forever waiting and hoping for a discount beyond -10%. Maybe this sale would be the sale, maybe the developer will have forgotten their promise that they will never discount more than 10%... maybe... just maybe... 

Well, they didn't and they probably won't, so after selling a bunch of steam cards and dota2 items I bought RimWorld with a dubious mind and every intention to refund it after 2 hours. 

20 hours later I was still playing. I've almost exclusively played this on Steam Deck and I'd dare say it is one of the best games out there to showcase the Deck. It draws little power, so the battery lasts forever, yet feels immense and completely immersive. 
The premise is simple - survive. Take your 3 little escape pod people and help them survive, give them tasks, collect metal, mine ores, build a little base and hope for the best. The game's tutorial is smooth as it leads you through the game's mechanics and game loop, but it doesn't expose all the secrets (which is the best part). 

The more you play the more game seems to let slip little tidbits of what you can do and the strange feeling of 'life' within this world you have landed on. You'll begin to feel some attachment to the plain looking crew you've assembled, even they do look like they've escaped from Prison Architect. This is the type of sandbox environment I like.

People keep coming and trying to trade, but to me they're a distraction from my sheep farm business. After I tamed that first sheep that was it. That was the game... breeding sheep and shearing their wool. Constantly. I have no idea if this is the actual game, but its the game I'm playing. Space Sheep. Cougar got into the sheep's little fenced off part of the world once... it sat there for a day, doing nothing. Then it attacked. I should have killed it. I wasn't going to make that mistake again. So I built spike traps around the outside of the fence. Nothing gets in now without get a spike trap around the head. 

Even THE PLAGUE can't kill off these sheep. 

Basically, RimWorld is a vast sandbox where there's a lot to do, but I've ignored it all to be a Space Sheep farmer. 

Research new things? Nah, I'll just look after me sheep.

Go exploring? Nah. Sheep. 

Maybe go on some of those random quests that pop up to gain new space tech and loot? Nope. No need for that, I've got me sheep. 

There's probably so much more to RimWorld that I haven't really experienced yet, but the 26.8 hours I've spent so far making this Space Sheep farm has been a blast.

123520659.review:
From cannibalistic blood reavers, theocratic cyborg transhumanists, Psy-Imperialists and Dave just looking for friends, RimWorld has a near limitless storytelling potential, rivaling the genre-giant Dwarf Fortress.

Every material has its own properties that make almost all of them useful (Slate maybe being the exception).
Characters have an in depth social history and it is always expanding, with your chosen cultural norms impacting that significantly. There are a number of endgame goals, of which you are locked into none. A savvy colony manager could keep the game into perpetuity if they wanted.

Faction politics are meaningful, you can trade, raid, adventure and plot. You can run a significant prison complex, a sacred druidic temple, black market cartel. There is a lot of potential and Im sure no one has done everything.

Its rare for a game to present such dynamic game play with relatively few limitations. The only one I can think of is not being able to run more than one colony, which does in its own way, limit your factions size. I'm not sure this is a bad thing, merely the games scope.

10/10 I have played over 1000 hours and I always find something new and fun to do

1190 hours, and that was all after I bought the official release, My actual time in the game is closer to double what's displayed on my profile, and you want to know what it has taught me?
This developer absolutely HATES the people who mod his game for free. He's never stated this, but his actions with the development of his game seem to differ...
I remember playing this game when it was still in early access, and being infinitely irritated every time a new update came out. Now why would I be mad about updates? Because for people who mod this game, and I'm one of the many who finds this game unplayable without mods, each update breaks every single mod you have installed, because the mods are rendered functionless until the author updates them to the current build. This acted like a sifter, each updates filtering out more and more flavor mods, because the author assumingly got frustrated and abandoned the mod.
When the 1.0 stable build came out, it was a golden age for modding.... Every mod was now perpetually valid as long as it didn't conflict with others you had running. Finally you could reliably run your favorite, personally flavored heavy-mod builds and invest untold hours into them knowing the game will finally have the depth that its potential allows. No more miles-wide ocean that only goes skin-deep (the problem that invariably plagues vanilla rimworld).... This was when I loved the game.
Then Tynan released the Royalty DLC.... This brought an end to the golden age of modding, ruined all my saves where I had invested countless hours into nurturing that stupid little colony through every hardship the game could throw at me. I was pissed enough to drop the game for the mean-time.
Years later I come back thinking it should now be on a stable build with biotech having been released months ago (how many more DLC's can Tynan really fart out? This isn't Paradox Interactive.... right?) Now a week later after getting a good mod list together and giving the game another go.... Ludeon releases ANOTHER piddly little update adding almost nothing to the game, and it breaks all of my saves and my entire mod list. Now it refuses to load my earlier saved mod-list, and keeps all of my 88 or so mods in a constant state of "now downloading"...
I believe I've found the fix through a pinned discussion link, but after dropping $25 on that damned Biotech DLC, I have absolutely no desire to spend another 2-4 hours just trying to resurrect my saves when Ludeon will just break them all again a month or 2 from now when they release the next piddling update.
Ludeon/Tynan, you are ruining your games by actively discouraging the mod base... the only actual life and soul behind the game you created... This game won't be truly great until you get out of the way and stop breaking it every 1-2 months.

137143377.review:
[b]Zzzt![/b]

Rimworld is a survival game that challenges players to manage resources and build a thriving colony on an alien planet. Rimworld has some pretty good graphics for a top-down colony sim, they're unique and leave the game easy on the eyes for continuous play.

Rimworld has an interesting relationship with its resource management. While it does provide a satisfying processing cycle for crafting items and gathering resources, the scarcity element entirely goes out the window once certain requirements are met. This leads to my believing that the game is intended to go from a 'survival of basics' (food, cover, medicine) to a 'survival of malice' (where pretty much the only threats are heavy disease and raids, which scale up in unfairness.).

The game's Steam Workshop is a highlight, with a thriving community of modders creating new content and expanding on the game's core mechanics. This adds a wealth of new options and customization to the game, with plenty of mods adding tons of new content, storytellers, etc. However, Rimworld's position as a 'story generator' usually doesn't amount to anything. While the game's basic survival formula is engaging and challenging, the story system rarely produces anything noteworthy outside of this formula. Without player intervention, most games will go extremely similar, with very few notable events or storylines emerging.

Despite the general repetitiveness of its gameplay, Rimworld remains a standout survival game that offers satisfying resource management gameplay. With its active Steam Workshop community, the game offers a wealth of options and customization that allow players to tailor their experience to their liking. If you're looking for a challenging survival game, Rimworld is an excellent choice, just don't expect the game's story system to provide much variety or surprise. The game goes on sale frequently for minor amounts, and I'd certainly recommend picking it up then.

100204167.review:
My entire colony was saved by a tortoise.

This won't be a review like the ones I normally do, going over the pros and cons. Rimworld's a story generator, so I thought I'd share my story. I bought rimworld around two weeks prior to writing this, and set up a small colony. The first animal my colonists tamed was a 212 year old tortoise, who I named "Old Timer." We set up a small farm, and once we found a female tortoise (who I named "Henrietta Peach"), they had kids. And their kids had kids. Soon enough, I had too many tortoises than I knew what to do with, so i tried selling them, and the nearby colonists loved them. But things took a darker turn.

Around 5 days after buying rimworld, my IRL dog, of 15 years, passed. It was sad, but what hit extra hard was old timer's death only a few hours later. Both were blind, both had bad backs - it hurt, and I cried. I dug a big tomb in a mountain for old timer, and laid him to rest in it. But this is not where his story ends.

A few ingame hours later, I got a quest with a ressurection serum as a reward. In that moment, I knew what I had to do, as the end goal of my playthrough.

I couldn't save my dog from old age, but I sure as could save this turtle. Old timer was going to space.

After quickly gunning down some tribals and getting the serum, I needed a way to keep old timer from dying all over again while I aquired the supplies for the ship. Luckily, an ancient ruin was on my map, and after an intense fight with some killer robots, I safely placed him in a stasis chamber the robots were guarding.

Not much happened relating to him. Henrietta died of old age herself, and over the four or so years it took me to complete the ship, old timer's children numbered over 500. i made regular trips to the nearby towns to trade tortoises for the ship's supplies, like plasteel and uranium, and at long last, I placed old timer in the now-finished ship and turned the reactor on.

When you power on the escape reactor, rimworld basically becomes a sort of wave defense game, with a new posse of enemies coming every day for 15 days or so while the reactor charged. This wasn't a big deal - I had troops in power armor with miniguns, and we made it to the end of the 15 days without any deaths. Right as the reactor was at full power, and I told my colonists to enter the ship, things took a dramatic turn. A solar flare knocked out all my defences, leaving me without any kind of fire support. I hurredly got my colonists in the ship, but right as the last one was making his way across the fields to get to it...

Pirates airdropped into my base. I was screwed.

I was about to launch without him, when salvation came in a way I hadn't expected: A tortoise (number 493, to be precise) didn't take too kindly to someone coming out of the sky and attempting to shoot his keepers, and bit a pirate enforcer on the leg. This caused the pirate to hit him with his club, and after that the OTHER pirates started shooting the hundred or so turtles in the base, who promptly attacked back. And, in the ensuing chaos, my last colonist boarded the ship and we escaped.

Old timer, a blind, crippled, undead tortoise repaid me for saving his life - by birthing countless decendants to not only fund my escape, but who also protected me in my darkest hour of need. This game is a gift, and I cannot reccommend it enough. Even if you reload saves to keep the story going how you want, it's still a story worth telling.

10/10: The first game to make me cry.

29332754.review:
[b] I felt like I had to share my experiences with RimWorld so far ...	[/b]

So I had just established my young but promising new colony, Ashton (a quite ironical name in the end ...). The basic needs were all covered, everyone had a nice place to sleep, decent clothing, enough to eat and time to relax. The people of Ashton were prosperous. They lived in harmony with nature and each other. Their wide fields provided them with plenty of food and they sold the surplus to the passing by caravans.
Now and then a few warriors of a near tribe, the Pig Face Men, attacked the settlement, but the people of Ashton were safe, relying on the strength of their automated defence systems. And so the colony grew and I thought: This is it, I finally have a colony which doesn't collapse after a few hours.

As if ...

Remember when I told you about the harmony between the people and with nature? I meant there were no rivalries between the colonists, most were friends and there even was a married couple, Tali and Waltz.
The harmony with nature also seems pretty coherent; the people relied mostly on their crops, eating only those animals which died by natural causes (e.g. old age or other animals), so the animal population in the near forests remained stable. So far so good. But taking those dead animals in meant of course someone had to leave the safe area of Ashton and wander through the wilds. Normally that wouldn't have been a problem, everyone was equipped with guns and armor of the Pig Face Men so they were quite ready to take on anything coming in their way.

[i] But then came the tortoise.	[/i]

Waltz left Ashton to get the still fresh corpse of a chinchilla which had been killed by some other animal. So Waltz has just grabbed it, when a tortoise nearby turned mad. I thought ok, those aren't that fast, Waltz will be able to safely carry the chinchilla inside and the turrets will take care of the tortoise. [b] Nope!	[/b] I'm not quite sure what exactly happened, maybe this animal was on speed or something like thak. Anyway, when it saw Waltz it charged at him at a horrifying pace. Waltz had just lifted his weapon when this damn creature reached and hurt him badly. However, its hard shell was no match for Waltz' gun. And so he came back home, injured but happy, that now there was even more meat than expected. But the wraith of the tortoise was unforgiving. The bite wounds in his upper body infected themselves. The medical treatment didn't work and he got weaker and weaker. If the infection at least would've been in one of his limbs, that might had saved him, but you can't just amputate someones chest.
At last he couldn't fight any longer, the infection overwhelmed him. Tali, his wife, carved his story in the sides of his sarcophagus. The burial ceremony was heartbreaking. Everyone had come: Tali, his sister Julia, his friends Vas, Jones, Stephan, Boyd and Leia, Vas' tame wolf Nevile and Bacon 1 and Bacon 2. In the light of the evening sun they all waved a last goodbye to their fallen husband, brother and friend, before the people of Ashton went to bed. With Waltz dead or not, they had to cary on.
But apparently it was all too much for Tali, not very surprising if you think about it. There was only this one little problem: She was a pyromaniac. When the rest of the colony slept, she left her big and empty bed. Driven crazy by grief, she did the only thing able to ease her pain. She set the forest on fire. Finally, exhausted almost to unconciousness, she fell back into her bed again.
While she slept, the others, waken by the crackling fire, desperately tried to put out the flames which already started to spread over to the buildings. But they simply weren't enough, they could either try to save the buildings or the forest, not both. Of course they tended to the buildings, to the food storage to be exact. However it gave the fire the chance to spread through the forest, completely sorrounding the settlement.
In the end it was all too much.
Tali died in her own fire that she refused to extinguish, Jones and Boyd followed when they collapsed in the infernal heat. And then, when no hope was left, the gods, the ancestors, the Flying Spaghetti Monster or whatever thi people of Ashton believed in, heard their cries. Rain started falling down, putting out the fire. But it was too late. More than three quarters of the colony had been taken by the flames. Vas, Stephan and Leia were unconcious. Julia was the only one still able to stand. She did what she could, but with all the medicine burned she had no chance. Leia died first, Vas second. This caused his wolf Nevile, who had been laying loyal by his side, to turn mad like the damn tortoise and he ripped the still unconcious Stehpan into pieces before he went on attacking a herd of muffalos (some kind of marshmellow like buffalos) which was his end.
Traumatised Julia, who managed to flee when Stephan was killed, wandered through the burnt ruins of Ashton. Blackened stone walls and pieces of charcoal everywhere. All the food they stored for the winter was gone, the fields empty. With no medicine left and her own wounds hurting worse and worse, Julia found a last smokeleaf joint in one of the destroyed buildings. She leant against her brother's sarcophagus and lit it. So she didn't feel anything when the Pig Face Men attacked. With the solar panels a loss to the flames, the turrets didn't react when Ashton's last inhabitant finally exhaled her last breath.


12 / 10 - Creates more immersive storys than many RPGs; looking forward to my next colony (and possibly its desastrous destruction ...).

Thanks for reading if you made it this far :-)

32163590.review:
If you're thinking of buying this game, stop hesitating and purchase it, immediately.

I started an isolated research facility on a frozen wasteland, as a 74-year-old sociopathic scientist called Geckulon Decktar; I researched robotics to begin with, and constructed some automatons to handle the menial tasks like cleaning, cooking and hauling, etc, leaving me free to conduct my research. All was well- until a band of savages laid siege to my settlement. I barely survived- but resolved to increase my security, installing several auto-turrets around my perimeter. This would keep the ruffians at bay for a time, but I needed a longer term solution- so I turned my focus to bionic enhancements.

I wanted to turn the human form into the ultimate living weapon. When a faction of slavers passed through my frozen wasteland, I did not hesitate to inspect their wares. I wanted a slave, but not just any slave- he should be foreboding, brutal and utterly without mercy! And that was when I found him. His name was Skint Mcgruff. He was a feared crime lord when they captured him, infamous for killing and then devouring the people who wronged him. I paid the slavers their due and took Skint in. I fed him (alas, not the human meat he desired, but nutrient paste, made from potatoes- poor fare, but such is life in the frozen wastes) and I clothed him.

By now I was confident in my ability to improve upon the human form, and so I presented the idea to him the very next day. He was keen- particularly about the notion of having retractable claws- and so the work began. My medical droid handled most of the surgery, but I crafted the bionic components myself. It was a long and grueling process, but eventually, he was complete. More machine now than man, I felt it necessary to rename him... to symbolise his departure from prosaic humanity to something more, and thus I named him C.A.N.N.I.B.A.L (Cybernetic Armoured Neutraliser with Neurally Integrated Bionic Attack Limbs). He is my pride and joy... bionic eyes that can see even in the dark, bionic legs that allow him to sprint faster than a cheetah, and retractable claws with which to tear out the throats of my foes, and of course, I give him leave to feast on their corpses afterward as a reward.

Now, I can finally conduct my research in peace...

44802498.review:
I've played RimWorld for [i]easily[/i] over 1000 hours aside from the 160+ hours on record for my account, I really should have reviewed it sooner since I've played it so long, but I never got around to it, so this'll include my experience in the game, what's good and bad, and everything you'd likely need to know before getting it.

To jump to my [b]conclusion:[/b] This game is fantastic if you like build a colony from the ground up, it's very interactive and you'll always have something to do, be it planning a new room for your base, building up defenses, creating a more reliable food source or even raiding enemy factions. At first it's very daunting as there is a lot to get used to, but each new discovery comes with a new way to experience the game, your story is always your own and it'll never be the same as before, lending this game to nigh-infinite replayability, and that's not even considering mods which are abundant, relatively easy to make yourself and very active. The developers constantly revise and improve aspects of the game improving it more and more as time passes, even your own ideas may be implemented if they're good additions to the game. The community is one of the best I've seen, where people joke around, share their playthroughs and wacky happenings whilst generally having a good time. I recommend this game if you like strategy, tackling positive/negative turn of events, planning things, and sandbox style survival games. If you're still on the fence for buying the game, watch a 'lets play' video and see madness that can occur, check out all the mods that are available and imagine the possibilities, it really is a great game.

[b]Art 8/10:[/b] The art style is quite minimalistic, at first it may be a turn-off but the style works well with the gameplay, with the attention you need to pay to so many things on screen it's good that the textures aren't complex, as it'd strain your eyes, whereas this style is soft on the eyes and doesn't impede the gameplay, things represent what they're meant to be, and it's surprisingly easy to get immersed into the game with the simplistic graphics.

[b]Story 10/10:[/b] This game is both heart breaking and hilarious, there is no set story, so things can go in any direction, you could have a trader caravan arrive to sell items just as a raid occurs, causing a massively shoot out between two major groups just outside your base, after which you can mop up all their valuables and turn their corpses into meals and skin, maybe for that human leather hat you've always wanted. Perhaps you start brewing beer only to have one of your pets drink some and get addicted to alcohol. Story is incredibly well done in this game, and with how fun it can be I'm surprised lots of other games don't use the same style.

[b]Sound 6/10:[/b] The sound is basic like the art, the sounds work for their intended purposes, there's nothing spectacular to talk about nor is there anything unique, the sound it has is right, but it's not something the game is well known for and isn't made to contribute a lot to the game.

[b]Gameplay 8/10:[/b] There are different types of games so I'll elaborate, for the style of game this is (a sci-fi colony sim) I'd say the gameplay is near perfect, and it can be perfected to a player's liking with mods, a lot of features from popular mods are incorporated into the game over time so the base game's gameplay will get even better over time. Things are placed using the UI at the bottom of the screen, and your colonists with build them if they have the resources, they can get the resources from your setting up of work orders (like cutting down trees, mining rocks, butchering animals, harvesting plants and various other ways). It's almost like you're the architect of a colony, telling them what needs to be done and when it needs to be done, it's quite nice as luck is a big factor, but foresight allows you to somewhat control your luck, and mitigate disaster, there's little that's more satisfying than diverting misfortune with a well thought out plan.

[b]Mods 9/10:[/b] Mods are very good for this game, some change the game entirely (like changing the space-cowboy style theme to that of Lord of the Rings, Medieval, WW2 era and many others), whilst others change / add to the games features and tools, allowing for you to adjust anything you don't like into something you do like, and the modding community is quite active, if there's a good idea for a mod then it's likely already made, If you choose to buy it then I recommend trying the base game without mods first, as whilst they add a lot to the game, they also take away from the main theme, playing it without mods will help you understand the fundamentals a lot quicker.

[b]Overall 9/10:[/b] The features individually would make the game an 8.2/10, but how they come together makes it a 9/10 for me, since RimWorld is the best game of it's type, I've looked long and hard for other games like it, and Prison Architect is the only game similar, but to me it doesn't have the random glory that RimWorld has. RimWorld is certainly worth £30, hell it's worth £50+ to me since I've got so much entertainment out of it, other games you may play for 200, maybe 300 hours, but this is one of those games which you can sink months into, and games like that are worth buying.

Thanks for reading my review if you did, I don't often write reviews but this game is just so good that I can't help but share my opinion.

54465321.review:
I've been playing this game for the first time and I want to share the story of how I realized it's kind of amazing.

The last of my three original colonists, a female trader named Onesan, died nine years after founding the colony. The story of her life on the planet is what amazed me and it convinced me this game is something special. It actually made me a little emotional. None of what I'm going to say is fake, this all happened.

Onesan arrived on the planet with her sister Min, a 16 year old K pop star, and her best friend August, a miner. Min died early on from injuries she took during a caravan ambush. Barely a year after that, August bled to death from injuries she received during a very bad pirate raid on the colony. Onesan broke down often in the early years.

By year three the only person Onesan knew well in the colony was her husband, Steel. Onesan and Steel had gone through a very rocky courtship. It took two years of awkward back and forth flirting before Steel finally won her over. But after three years of marriage, Steel was seduced by another colonist, and Onesan separated from him. Despite Steel's cheating she never broke down again. She couldn't afford to. She was the colony's lead trader and negotiator. Onesan was always busy, constantly on the road between her colony and the friendly one nearby. During the periods when she wasn't on the road, she tailored clothes for the rest of the colony. Steel stayed on his side of the colony, working on armor and weapons. 

For years they rarely ran into each other despite the relatively small size of the colony. Eventually, the relationship with the neighboring colonies changed, and the trade deals began to dry up. After her final return trip, Onesan was suddenly very eager to be with her estranged husband again. It seemed like all the time and distance apart helped her to forgive him. In a strange cosmic coincidence, Steel had broken up with the other colonist while Onesan had been away on her last trip. They got back together, and for one more year they enjoyed each other more than they ever had before. 

On the day she died, Onesan was hunting near the edge of the map, far away from the colony. A large pack of manhunting arctic wolves entered the map almost on top of her. Onesan was ripped to shreds and bled to death before Steel and everyone else had even left the safety of the walls. 

As the final member of the original colonists and the colony's informal leader, Onesan deserved the best possible funeral. A catacomb was excavated for her deep inside the nearby mountain, and a solid silver sarcophagus was placed inside for her to rest in. Steel constructed the sarcophagus for his wife personally. It was excellent quality.

He titled the sarcophagus Shadow of Onesan. The description reads:

"The sarcophagus is engraved with a picture of Ryoko 'Onesan' Minase practicing construction skills with visible exhaustion. Hundreds of cowboys watch with amazement. The work seems to represent suffering. The lower part of the image is dominated by a large group of shamans. This representation tells the story of Onesan becoming a master at construction tasks on 5th of Septober, 5509."

You can see a screenshot I took of it here. https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/781857270461047007/2BD4EB8FCD3C4627D00A25CDB42AC71B4F179355/

I'm not sure why, but Onesan's death did not make Steel upset. I know she was important to him, though. He would leave his work at the machining bench all the time to visit her sarcophagus. He'd always be there for a long time, staring down at it. I've been paying closer attention to him since Onesan died, and as far as I can tell he hasn't flirted with any of the other colonists since her death.

Eventually I decided that Steel was going to focus on leading Onesan's people off the planet. Now he sits at the research bench every day, slowly unlocking the path to the stars. 

I like to imagine that someday when the ship is ready he will send her people off, but instead of going with them he will stay behind on the planet to be with her.
